Graphical abstract The graphical abstract highlights the hyperbranched anion exchange membranes with linear, dendritic, and terminal units for efficient hydrogen production in water electrolysis. Anion-exchange membrane water electrolysers (AEMWEs) and fuel cells (AEMFCs) are critical technologies for converting renewable resources into green hydrogen (H2), where anion-exchange membranes (AEMs) play a vital role in efficiently transporting hydroxide ions (OH−) and minimizing fuel crossover, thus enhancing overall efficiency. While conventional AEMs with linear, side-chain, and block polymer architectures show promise through functionalization, their long-term performance remains a concern. To address this, hyperbranched polymers offer a promising alternative due to their three-dimensional structure, higher terminal functionality, and ease of functionalization. This unique architecture provides interconnected ion transport pathways, fractional free volume, and enhanced long-term stability in alkaline environments. Recent studies have achieved conductivities as high as 304.5 mS cm−1, attributed to their improved fractional free volume and microphase separation in hyperbranched AEMs. This review explores the chemical, mechanical, and ionic properties of hyperbranched AEMs in AEMFCs and assesses their potential for application in AEMWEs. Strategies such as blending and structural functionalisation have significantly improved the properties by promoting microphase separation and increasing the density of cationic groups on the polymer surface. The review provides essential insights for future research, highlighting the challenges and opportunities in developing high-performance hyperbranched AEMs to advance hydrogen energy infrastructure. Keywords Hydrogen Hyperbranched anion exchange membrane Anion exchange membrane fuel cell Alkaline stability Microphase separation Fractional free volume Anion exchange membrane water electrolysers 1 Introduction 1.1 Hydrogen A significant increase in energy consumption, driven by a growing global population and extensive industrialization across sectors spanning agriculture to automobiles, has been witnessed over the past two centuries [1,2]. This increased reliance on fossil fuels for energy needs has led to higher carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions as shown in Fig. 1 , that most of the industrially developed countries have highest emissions of CO2 contributing significantly to the global warming crisis, which in turn has far-reaching consequences for the environment, economy, and society as a whole [3]. So there is an urgent need to explore alternative sources of energy which is renewable and have lower CO2 emissions. While the energy sources like solar [4], wind [5], and hydroelectric power [6] are crucial in reducing our dependence on fossil fuels and mitigating climate change, there is also a tremendous potential for hydrogen to play a significant role in reducing our reliance on fossil fuels and promoting a sustainable future. Just as a tree with multiple branches yields enough fruits, a sustainable energy future also requires multiple branches to yield clean energy solutions. By integrating variety of renewable energy source along with hydrogen, we can collectively harvest energy requirements and ensure a sustainable and resilient future for upcoming generations [7]. As a lightest and most abundant element in the universe, hydrogen has gained significant attention in recent years as an energy vector due to its net-zero carbon footprint that could play a major role in transitioning towards a sustainable energy future [8]. It is a clean fuel, that produces energy/electricity with the emission of only water vapor and heat when utilized, with no greenhouse gas emissions, indicating its versatility and potential to decarbonize various sectors, such as transportation, industries, and power generation [9,10]. Hence, the promising aspects of hydrogen utilization demands cost effective and efficient production technologies in transforming the current energy infrastructure towards a sustainable future. It can be produced by employing various feedstocks using different methodologies. The flexibility in terms of sourcing and production methods, depending on the availability of resources and local conditions indicates the promising future of hydrogen-based future infrastructure. Furthermore, hydrogen could be produced onsite at remote locations depending on the demand, thus making it as a viable option for energy storage and distribution. Therefore, a greater advancement towards hydrogen production and utilization can have a significant impact on reducing carbon emissions and achieving a sustainable future. The production of hydrogen can be achieved through various methodologies, having several advantages and challenges [11]. Recently, water electrolysis (WE) technology has been getting significant attention due to its profound advantages which involve the use of electricity from renewable resources to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen gas [12]. On the other hand, steam methane reforming (SMR) is known to be a widely used and established technology that involves the reaction of natural gas and steam to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide [13]. Similarly, the thermochemical processes utilize heat and chemical reactions to extract hydrogen from biomass or fossil fuel feedstocks [14]. Hydrogen could also be generated using microorganisms (such as cyanobacteria or algae), through biological processes like photosynthesis or fermentation [15]. However, among the currently available technologies, the WE emerges as an ideal technology for the sustainable production of hydrogen as it utilizes solar or wind energy, as both sources are renewable and emit no greenhouse gases during operation. Relying on green hydrogen production technologies ensures the reduction of dependency on fossil fuels and helps to mitigate climate change by reducing carbon dioxide emissions [16]. This reduces the need for extracting and transporting fossil fuels, minimizing associated risks and costs while supporting the transition to a sustainable low-carbon energy system [17]. Importantly, utilizing solar or wind energy for hydrogen production promotes energy independence and security as these resources are abundant and domestically available. 1.2 Water electrolysis (WE) Water electrolysis is a promising technique for producing high-quality hydrogen through electrochemical conversion, which involves breaking down water into hydrogen and oxygen using electricity. This method could play a significant role in generating hydrogen using renewable energy, and the hydrogen produced can be used for heating and energy storage. Notably, excess energy can be stored as hydrogen through water electrolysis, which can later be utilized in fuel cells to produce electricity. The overall reaction process of water splitting is summarized below in below Eqs. (1)–(5). (1) 2H2O → 2H2 + O2, E⁰ = 1.229 V In an acidic environment, the reactions at the electrodes are Cathode (negative): (2) 2H+ + 2e− → H2, E⁰ = 0 V Anode (positive): (3) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e−, E⁰ = 1.23 V In an alkaline environment, the reactions at the electrodes are Cathode (negative): (4) 2H2O + 2e− → H2 + 2OH−, E⁰ = −0.83 V Anode (positive): (5) 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e−, E⁰ = 0.40 V Water electrolysis is advantageous in both acidic and alkaline conditions due to the availability of water molecules in deprotonated form for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in alkaline solutions and protonated form for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in acidic solutions. The production of hydrogen through water electrolysis requires a minimum free energy of 237.2 kJ mol−1 at STP (standard temperature and pressure) conditions [18]. The water-splitting process occurring in a low temperature electrolyser <100 °C consists of two electrodes (anode and cathode) and an electrolyte, which can be liquid electrolyte or a solid hydrated polymer electrolyte or a mixture of both. The electrolysers are typically divided into, alkaline electrolysers use an aqueous alkaline solution or electrolyte (e.g KOH) and non-noble metal electrodes (such as nickel) [19]; proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysers that employs a (hydrated) solid polymer electrolyte membrane conducting protons and use noble metal catalysts like platinum and iridium [20]; and anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysers, an emerging technology using a hydrated anion-conducting membrane, but often with addition of supporting liquid KOH electrolyte, that allows non-noble metal catalysts and potentially lowers costs [21]; solid oxide electrolysis cells (SOECs) operating at high temperature >600 °C with steam, utilize a solid ceramic electrolyte, that conducts oxygen ions (O2−) [22]. In all of the above-mentioned electrolysers, an electrochemical reaction initiates the electrolysis that includes oxygen evolution at the anode and hydrogen evolution at the cathode. Compared to the conventional method of hydrogen extraction, the electrolysis offers high-purity hydrogen, modularity, scalability, and integration with renewable energy. However, the electrolysis process faces several challenges such as high costs, durability, scalability, and efficiency, and thus requires further advancements. 1.3 Anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) Among the electrolysers, alkaline water electrolysis (AWE) has historically played a crucial role in the development of water electrolyser systems, leveraging on alkaline electrolytes such as potassium hydroxide or sodium hydroxide to efficiently split water into hydrogen and oxygen gases under the applied potential [23], as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). In AWE systems the anode and cathode compartments are separated using a diaphragm that inhibits the mixing of H2 and O2. However, AWE systems face challenges such as low current density, which affects the cost of hydrogen production, and gas purity, slowly start up dynamics and high minimum load >10% making integration with intermittent renewables more challenging, and corrosion issues, leading to higher maintenance costs. Subsequent advancements in membrane-based WE systems reveal the use of a membrane that divides the anode and the cathode compartment by a solid polymer electrolyte that systematically regulates the ion transport while reducing gas permeation to enhance the efficiency and H2 purity. In the last few decades, proton exchange membrane-based electrolysers (PEMWE) were developed that utilize a solid polymer electrolyte to conduct protons between the anode and cathode side, while separating the produced H2 and O2 gases as illustrated in Fig. 2(b). Despite some advantages, the reliance of PEMWE on precious metal catalysts further limits its application and cost. Considering the challenges and limited advantages of AWE and PEMWE systems, alternate technologies were explored. Specifically, AEMWE technology was developed, by combining the advantages of both AWE and PEMWE technologies. Mainly, the ability to utilize non-precious metal catalysts and titanium free bipolar plates. Mild basic electrolyte conditions not only position AEMWE as a cost-effective alternative but also as a sustainable solution in the hydrogen energy sector. A comparative analysis has been done in Table 1 [24,25] for the three electrolysers to facilitate easy understanding. The progression of AEMs has been marked by several important milestones [26–28]. AEM, a critical part of AEMWE is a semi-permeable membrane containing cationic head groups attached to polymer backbones. The structural arrangement of AEM allows the effective repelling of the cations while facilitating the efficient diffusion pathways for the electrolyte anions. In AEMWE, the primary role of the AEM is to transport OH− ions from the cathode to the anode as illustrated in Fig. 2(c), and at the same time curbing gas movement and enabling electron transfer during electrochemical reactions. The AEMs typically comprise a hydrocarbon polymer and an anion exchange functional group, forming the main and side chains, respectively. However, fabricating AEMs that balance mechanical stability and high ionic conductivity remains challenging due to alkaline working conditions in the stack systems. While AEM can provide facile hydroxide ion conductivity >0.1 S cm−1, a supporting electrolyte ≥ 0.1 M KOH (usually 0.1–1 M) is required for anode catalysis, e.g., for formation of oxyhydroxide active species. The membrane's chemical stability is generally compromised when hydroxide ions pose a risk of attack on the functional cationic groups and the polymer backbone. Hence, the long-term stability and continued operation remain areas of concern for AEMWE development with limited stability data in the literature and one of the longest long-term tests showing lifetime in order of 10,000 h well short of targets of 60,000–80,000 h. Consequently, extensive research is being conducted to develop AEM materials with enhanced chemical stability and ionic conductivity in alkaline environments [29] for the ideal operation of AEMWE systems. Given this, several AEMs have been developed which exhibited impressive commercial applicability in WE systems. Table 2 provides a selective overview of the properties of various commercial AEMs from manufacturers such as Fumatech, Tokuyama, Ionomr, Dioxide Materials, and Orion Polymer by gathering from technical data sheets and previous studies [30]. Despite these commercial membranes, the long-term operation of AEMWE systems with significant stability and efficiency remains a challenge. Hence, a new strategy and effective implementation and optimization of AEM are essential. Focusing on the membrane and advantageous AEMWE technology, several reviews have been reported primarily focused on linear polymer-based AEMWE and challenges in AEMWE components, as Fig. 3 shows the trends in the number of annual publications concerning AEMWE applications. The literature survey reveals that no significant reviews have been focused on the study of the effect of hyperbranching in AEMs for AEMFC and AEMWE applications. Hence, the current review distinguishes itself by thoroughly examining the hyperbranched AEM structures and their influence on AEM properties in AEMFC and for a possible application in AEMWE systems. 1.4 Anion exchange membrane fuel cell (AEMFC) In general, fuel cell is an electrochemical device that converts the chemical energy of a fuel, such as hydrogen, directly into electrical energy through an electrochemical reaction [31]. Unlike traditional combustion-based power generation, fuel cells operate with high efficiency and produce zero harmful emissions, making them a promising technology for sustainable energy production [32]. The basic principle of a fuel cell involves the oxidation of a fuel at the anode and the reduction of an oxidant, typically oxygen or air, at the cathode. This reaction generates electricity, water, and heat [33]. Low-temperature fuel cells, such as proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC), alkaline fuel cells (AFCs), and anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs), operate below 100 °C and are known for their rapid start-up, high electrochemical efficiency. AFCs use hydrogen as fuel at the anode while consuming oxygen at the cathode to produce electricity through the redox reactions at the anode and cathode with diaphragm filled with potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution as the electrolyte as shown Fig. 4 (a). PEMFCs use a proton-conducting membrane as the solid electrolyte and operate in an acidic environment, where protons are transported from the anode to the cathode through the PEM where the primary reaction in PEMFCs involves hydrogen molecules losing electrons at the anode, with hydrated protons traveling through the membrane to the cathode, where they react with oxygen to form water as shown Fig. 4(b) [34]. AEMFCs, on the other hand, employ an a hydrated or humidified AEM that conducts hydroxide ions (OH−) in an alkaline environment without any supporting electrolyte. In AEMFCs, oxygen is reduced at the cathode to form hydroxide ions, which then travel through the membrane to the anode, where they react with hydrogen to produce water as shown Fig. 4(c) [35]. AEMFCs have gained significant attention due to their potential advantages over PEMFCs include the ability to use non-precious metal catalysts, possibility of using various fuels like methanol, ethanol, and ammonia and it does not require expensive fluorinated feedstocks, potentially lowering the cost of ion exchange membranes [36]. However, several challenges remain for AEMFCs such as the diffusion coefficient of OH− ions is significantly lower than that of H+ ions, resulting in lower conductivity [37]. Moreover, the stability of the AEM under high temperatures and alkaline conditions is a concern, as it impacts the durability of the fuel cell [38]. The main challenge in AEM and ionomers under fuel cell operations is the water transport management and the drying of the cathode (water is a reactant) which leads to rapid degradation of the functional groups due to increase nucleophilicity of OH− ion. It is noteworthy to mention that anode flooding is a significant issue resulting from the accumulation of excess water at the anode. This water is electrochemically generated through the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) and is also transported from the cathode via electro-osmotic drag, a process that occurs in the reverse direction compared to PEMFCs [39]. Adequate hydration of the anode is crucial to prevent flooding, as excessive water accumulation in the catalyst and gas diffusion layers impedes reactant access, thereby reducing the achievable current and power densities. The delicate balance between sufficient hydration and water management is challenging, as even slight water imbalances can lead to flooding and poor cell performance. Various approaches, such as optimizing membrane properties to enhance water back diffusion and better regulate hydration, are being investigated to address this issue [40,41]. However, achieving high-performance AEMFCs while effectively mitigating anode flooding remains a critical area of research. Despite these challenges, the development of new materials and optimization strategies has led to significant performance improvements in AEMFCs, making them a promising technology for the future of low-temperature fuel cells. A comparative analysis has been done in Table 3 [42,43] for the discussed three fuel cells to facilitate easy understanding. 2 Polymer and cations in AEMWE and AEMFC 2.1 Polymer backbone Polymeric backbone used in AEM plays a vital role in determining their alkaline stability, mechanical properties, and ion transport efficiency. Various polymers have been explored for AEMFCs and AEMWE, as illustrated in Fig. 5 (a–c), which includes polyethylene such as low-density polyethylene (LDPE) or high-density polyethylene (HDPE) [44,45], polypropylene (PP) [46], polynorborene [47], poly(phenyleneoxide) (PPO) [48], poly(ethersulfone) (PES) [49], poly(arylene ether sulfone) (PAES) [50], polysulfone (PSF) [51], polyether ketone (PEK) [52], polybenzimidazole (PBI) [53], polyphenylene [54], polyfluorene [55], poly(vinyl benzyl chloride) [56], poly(aryl piperdinium) [57], poly(styrene) [58], poly(ether ether ketone) (PEEK) [59], chitosan (CS) [60], cellulose [61], polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) [62], styrene-ethylene butylene styrene (SEBS) [63], poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) [64], and ethylene-tetrafluoroethylene (ETFE) [65]. However, their molecular structure and architecture of these polymers significantly influence the alkaline stability of the AEM due to backbone degradation in highly basic environments. Polyaromatic backbones having aromatic rings within their structures include PPO, PES, PAES, PSF, PEEK, polyphenylene, and polyfluorene and aryl-ether (C–O) linkages which typically provide high mechanical stability and thermal resistance. However, aliphatic backbone such as polyethylene (LDPE and HDPE), PP, polynorbornene, and SEBS are characterized by carbon–carbon single bonds that offer good resistance to alkaline degradation, still these aliphatic polymers are more prone to oxidative degradation due to the susceptibility of C–C bonds to attack by free radicals. The presence of ether linkages in some of these backbones can render them vulnerable to alkaline degradation [66–69]. The C–O bonds are particularly prone to attack under high pH conditions, where hydroxide ions induce scission, weakening the polymer which require further functionalisation to enhance its performance. Among those, PES has been shown to have poor alkaline stability due to the presence of strong electron-withdrawing groups [70–73]. However, recently Chen et al. [49] has introduced a photoinitiated bromination process targeting methyl groups on tolyl substituents in PES-based AEMs, followed by quaternization. This selective bromination method focused on methyl groups rather than the main chain, which helps maintain the polymer’s structural integrity. However, the susceptibility of these C–O bonds to nucleophilic attack causes considerable performance degradation, prompting researchers to explore aryl-ether-free alternatives. One such promising approach involve using PBI and pyridine-bridged structures that incorporate cationic groups such as pyridinium and imidazolium which minimizes ether linkages, resulting in stable OH− conductivity where further alkylation shown improvements in both alkaline stability and ionic conductivity of the membrane. Alternatively fluorinated polymers like PTFE and ETFE are known for their exceptional chemical resistance, making them highly stable in both alkaline and oxidative environments. Their fluorinated backbones impart hydrophobicity, enhancing the durability of AEMs in harsh conditions, which is especially advantageous for long-term applications in challenging operational environments. In addition, biopolymers such as CS, cellulose, and PVA are low carbon footprint-based material that bring functional groups conducive to ion transport. However, to improve their alkaline stability and mechanical strength, these biopolymers often require additional treatments like crosslinking or other modifications. These materials are attractive for applications aiming for sustainability, though they typically need enhancement to meet durability requirements for AEMs. In addition, polymers like poly(vinyl benzyl chloride), poly(aryl piperidinium), and poly(styrene) are notable for their readily modifiable backbone. In our study [44,45], we have shown that branched LDPE polymer are easier to functionalise and show better conductivity than linear LDPE. It is to be mentioned that distribution of functional group on backbone not only influence conductivity but also degradation rate by affecting number of functional groups lost per OH– attack. 2.2 Polymer architecture In addition to backbone structure the architecture plays a vital role chemical stability. Main-chain AEMs In main-chain AEMs, where ionic groups are close to the polymer backbone, OH− ions can attack and degrade the polymer, leading to reduced mechanical properties and ionic conductivity. For instance, PBI even though it has imidazole-based backbone, exhibit low alkaline stability, however introduction of methyl groups near the imidazole on the benzene ring improves its alkaline stability by providing steric hindrance [74]. Side-chain AEMs In contrast, side-chain AEMs, with ionic groups placed on flexible side chains, improve stability by promoting ion cluster formation and enhancing hydrophilic/hydrophobic microphase separation. This architecture leads to better ion mobility, conductivity, and stability, while controlling swelling and allowing efficient ion transport. Studies by Li et al. [75] demonstrated that side-chain quaternised poly(arylene ether sulfone) (PAES-Q) AEMs outperform main-chain versions in both conductivity and stability, with longer alkyl side chains further enhancing hydrophobicity and dimensional stability. Block-chain AEMs Block AEMs, which consist of distinct hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments, also improve phase separation and ion transport, though large ion channels can cause excessive swelling, compromising mechanical integrity. Lin et al. [76] synthesized a triblock AEM with hydrophobic PES and hydrophilic polyphenyl ether segments, achieving effective phase separation. By positioning the cationic groups in the hydrophilic blocks away from the sulfone groups, they improved alkaline stability while maintaining toughness and flexibility, resulting in strong chemical resilience. Further it substantiate that backbone modifications in AEM are essential therefore to improve ionic conductivity and stability. Given this, various techniques including grafting, blending [77] and copolymerization [78] techniques are explored which are aimed to address issues related to alkaline stability, ion transport efficiency, hydrophilicity and long-term operation with cost effectiveness. More recently, exploring hyperbranched polymers provides a promising alternative for developing efficient and stable AEMs. Their unique 3D architectures allow for controlled distribution of functional groups, enhanced ion clustering, and a high degree of tunability for stability and performance optimization. 2.3 Cation groups Cationic groups in AEM are responsible for the ion exchange and ionic mobility properties through the membranes, during AEMWE and AEMFC operation. The cationic groups are positively charged, which attract and facilitate the movement of negatively charged ions (anions) by selective transport across the membrane [79]. Because, selectivity is a vital aspect of WE, where it aids in the transport of hydroxide ions from the cathode to the anode while preventing the migration of other undesired ions [80]. However, upon use of supporting electrolyte with KOH the selectivity of the AEM decrease compared to use of de-ionised water and transport of K+ across the AEM can occur depending on level of electrolyte uptake and swelling. Furthermore, cationic groups significantly impact the water uptake, stability and durability of the membrane under harsh operating conditions [81]. Also, the incorporation of cationic groups allows facile control over the morphology and pore structure of the membranes, leading to improved performance and efficiency. The commonly used cation groups in AEMs are quaternary ammonium (QA), imidazolium, pyrrolidinium, pyridinium, guanidium and phosphonium ions and it is worth to mention that nitrogen spiro-cycles e.g., 6-azonia-spiro [5.5] undecane bromide (ASU) and isoindoline are recently getting attention due to their potential to shield reactive sites from degradation, although their bulkiness may slightly impede ion movement in some cases yet they provide structural support, helping the membrane maintain its integrity and functionality under stress. 2.3.1 Quaternary ammonium ions The QA ions are widely used group in AEM due to it facile synthesis procedure and its structure consist of nitrogen atom bonded to four alkyl groups, giving them a permanent positive charge ideal for attracting and binding anions and it also have high PKa ensuring effective ion exchange [82]. Furthermore, their structural properties provide effective control over the pore structure and morphology of the AEM, leading to improved performance and efficiency in AEMWE and AEMFC [83,84]. However, QA's long-term use is limited by low alkaline stability and the main routes of degradation are thought to involve nucleophilic substitution and β-elimination at the QA sites due to reactions with OH– ions as shown in Fig. 6 (a). Additionally, depending on the QA structure, degradation pathways may occur, such as ortho substitution, rearrangement reactions involving benzyl ammonium compounds, or Stevens rearrangement when β-protons are absent. Additionally cyclic QA salts have better base stability than long alkyl-chain QA salts because the conformation of cyclic QA salts is not conducive to Hofmann elimination [85]. Marino et al. [86] reported that the most stable QA studied is 6-azonia-spiro[5.5]undecane (ASU), which exhibits remarkable resistance to both nucleophilic substitution and β-elimination, despite the presence of four β-protons in an antiperiplanar arrangement. This enhanced stability is attributed to the unfavorable bond angles and bond lengths in the transition states of these degradation pathways. Conversely, benzylic QAs were found to be particularly susceptible to nucleophilic attack, especially when electron-withdrawing substituents were present on the aromatic ring, further increasing their reactivity and it should be avoided. Eventhough, recently there are many studies which employed cyclic QA and attained high stability, it is noteworthy to mention that QA compound stability can vary between single molecules and polymer matrices. For instance, ASU cations, stable in isolation, shows degradation via Hofmann β-elimination when embedded in a polymer. This underscores the need to assess ion-exchange group stability both independently and within the polymer to ensure reliable performance, especially as rigid polymer backbones may impact stability through bond distortion and restricted flexibility [87]. 2.3.2 Imidazolium ions Imidazolium ions are characterized by a five-membered ring structure containing two nitrogen atoms, one of which is positively charged and have demonstrated significant potential as cationic groups in AEMs as they can accommodate various substituents and its internal π-π conjugation within the imidazole ring enhances its alkaline stability by delocalizing the positive charge, making it less prone to degradation in alkaline environment [88]. However, its alkaline stability is influenced by substitution position, steric hindrance, and the presence of electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups, leading to variations in its stability. Huger et al. [89] shows the degradation pathways for imidazolium cations under alkaline conditions, primarily driven by nucleophilic substitution and rearrangement reactions as show in Fig. 6(b). The central imidazolium ring undergoes various breakdown processes depending on the substituents (R1, R2, etc.) attached to different positions on the ring. For instance, when R2 is hydrogen (H), nucleophilic substitution at position 2, while alkylation reactions can occur when R1 and R3 (such as benzyl or methyl groups) are attacked by nucleophiles like OH− resulting in substituted heterocyclic rings. Rearrangement pathways, such as Stevens rearrangement, can also occur when groups like R1 = CH3 migrate, leading to the formation of rearranged five-membered rings. Additionally, pathways involving benzylic or ethyl groups may undergo β-elimination, releasing HX and forming different heterocyclic structures. However, through systematic substitution at key positions such as C2 with electron donating group enhances stability by providing steric hindrance that blocks nucleophilic attacks. The most stable imidazolium cations were those with C2, C4, and C5 methyl groups and butyl groups at the nitrogen sites, showing minimal degradation [90,91]. However, there exists a trade-off between stability and ionic conductivity in imidazolium compounds, while they offer better alkaline stability, their ionic conductivity often lags behind that of QA groups and grafting both QA and imidazolium helps to balance both, as Li et al. incorporated halogenated alkyl chains, by grafting of both QA and imidazolium onto a fluorene-biphenyl backbone via super acid catalysed polymerization, effectively enhancing conductivity without compromising stability [79]. Therefore, structural characteristics of imidazolium ions particularly their ring structure and charge delocalization, could be correlated directly to their high performance in AEMs, making them highly suitable for WE and AEMFC [92,93]. 2.3.3 Pyrrolidinium ions Pyrrolidinium-based cationic groups have unique structural attributes, which contribute to both chemical stability and ionic conductivity. The structure of the pyrrolidinium ion consists of a positively charged nitrogen atom within a five-membered ring, that could provide significant stability to the cationic group. The ring structure of the pyrrolidinium system mitigates the susceptibility towards Hofmann elimination and nucleophilic attack, which are the main degradation pathways on AEMs in electrolysers and fuel cells. The compact and symmetric nature of the ring promotes efficient packing within the polymer matrix that facilitates the formation of well-defined ion transport channels for OH− transport [94,95]. However, in alkaline environments, pyrrolidinium cations are prone to degradation via nucleophilic attack by OH− ions, leading to ring-opening and the formation of a less stable open-chain structure, which compromises their chemical stability as shown in Fig. 6(c). Gu et al. [94] through their theoretical studies using Mulliken charge population analysis and density functional theory (DFT) calculations confirmed that the ring-opening reaction primarily occurs at the α-carbon. The energy barrier (E barrier) represents the energy required for OH− to attack the cation, with higher E barrier values indicating greater alkaline stability. Among the studied pyrrolidinium cations 1-ethyl-1-methylpyrrolidinium [EMPy]+ exhibited the highest E barrier value of 36.11 kcal mol−1, indicating higher energy will be required for OH− to attack the cation and it denotes that [EMPy]+ is the most stable cation in strongly basic solutions, particularly at elevated temperatures. 2.3.4 Pyridinium ions The pyridinium moieties in AEMs systems are derived from pyridine consisting of a six-membered aromatic ring of the pyridinium ion, with a positively charged nitrogen atom. The chemical and structural properties of pyridinium ions ensure stability and efficient OH− transport. Within the AEM, the planar structure of the pyridinium ring facilitates the formation of organized ionic channels, enhancing IEC and conductivity [96,97]. However, their alkaline stability remains a challenge when OH− ions are abundant. The degradation mechanism typically involves a nucleophilic attack by OH− on the positively charged nitrogen in the pyridinium ring, leading to a disruption of the aromaticity [85] as shown in Fig. 6(d). This results in a 6π-electrocyclic ring opening, forming a less stable intermediate that is susceptible to further hydrolysis. The hydrolysis cleaves the pyridinium ring, generating by-products such as substituted amines and carbonyl compounds, which further degrade under alkaline conditions. Consequently, while pyridinium cations offer some advantages in terms of conductivity and structural organization, their susceptibility to nucleophilic attack significantly limits their long-term alkaline stability in AEM applications. Enhancing alkaline stability can be achieved by increasing steric hindrance around electrophilic sp 2 carbon centers, preventing nucleophilic attacks. 2.3.5 Phosphonium ions Phosphonium ions consist of a positively charged phosphorus atom bonded to four alkyl or aryl groups, linked to the carbon backbone. The unique structure of phosphonium ions contributes to the ion conductivity and improved mechanical stability of the membranes [98]. However, the degradation is influenced by the higher electronegativity and polarizability of phosphorus compared to nitrogen, which increases its electron-withdrawing ability [99,100]. This leads to a more acidic α-hydrogen in the alkyl group adjacent to the phosphonium group, making it more susceptible to hydroxide attack as shown in Fig. 6(e) [85]. As a result, quaternary phosphonium salts exhibit lower alkaline stability than quaternary ammonium salts. However, base stability can be enhanced by introducing quaternary phosphonium cations with electron donating methoxy groups can overcome diminished electron density of phosphonium within the benzene ring when improving steric hindrance [101,102] and Gu et al. [101] reported that the conductivity loss of their polysulfone (PSF)-based AEMs, which were remained below 20% at 80 °C for 5000 h. This stability was attributed to the methoxy groups electron-donating effect and the spatial resistance of the benzene ring. 2.3.6 Guanidinium ions In guanidinium ions, the positive charge is evenly distributed across the three nitrogen atoms due to resonance, contributing to their notable thermal and chemical stability [103]. In alkaline conditions, hydroxide ions initiate an attack on the central carbon of the guanidinium group, leading to the formation of a reactive intermediate. This intermediate then undergoes further degradation, resulting in the formation of end products such as tetramethylurea (TMU) and a secondary amine as shown in Fig. 6(f) and the degradation ultimately results in the loss of ionic conductivity [104]. However, various approach has been explored on enhancing the performance of guanidinium such as increasing the phenyl rings which enhances volume and steric hindrance leads to improved stability [105]. Further, electrondonating methyl group also enhanced the chemical stability as shown by Xie et al. [104]. Although different approach on guanidinium-functionalized AEMs have been proposed to improve their stability, still there is a limitation in maintaining a balance between conductivity and stability and requires further research on substitution. In addition, the other cationic groups in AEMs include sulfonium ions [106], phosphazenium ions [107], and metal cation [108] which are known to enhance the performance and stability of AEMs. Specifically metal cations have unique advantage over organic cations due to their stability, higher valence and subsequent association with multiple anions [109]. Multivalent metal cations, like bis(terpyridine)ruthenium [110] and permethylcobaltocenium [111] exhibit strong alkaline stability, making them suitable for high-temperature conditions. Additionally, crown ethers can host specific metal ions (e.g., Na+, K+), enhancing ionic conductivity through their hydrophilic nature, which improves water uptake and forms structured ion pathways within the membrane [112–114]. Therefore, the incorporation of diverse cationic groups in a range of polymer backbones leads to the tuning and designing of a wide range of AEMs, which could enhance the overall performance of AEM [115]. Overall, AEMs are considerably less stable in alkaline environments compared to PEMs in acidic conditions [116]. Hydroxide-induced degradation can occur both at the polymer backbone and at the functional group, where degradation of the polymer backbone leads to chain scission, reduces the molecular weight. This reduction increases the brittleness of the membrane, a problem particularly pronounced in the presence of aromatic ether groups [68]. Besides AEMs can degrade through oxidative degradation [117], when a oxidative species generated during electrochemical reactions can attack the polymer backbone or functional groups, leading to chain scission and loss of mechanical properties. Additionally, high temperatures can lead to thermal decomposition of the polymer matrix and functional groups [118], affecting structural and chemical stability. It can also lead to dehydration which increases the nucleophilicity of OH− and its potency in nucleophilic attacks. Research on more stable cationic headgroup towards oxidation and nucleophilic attacks continues. While lifetime of excess of 100,000 h are reported for functional groups alone in hydrated solutions [119], lifetime in AEM electrolysers and in operando tests are significantly shorter. 2.4 Scope of hyperbranched architectures Though linear polymer backbones in AEMs typically exhibit significant mechanical strength and thermal stability, relying solely on a linear polymer backbone for AEMWE and AEMFC presents several significant challenges. Linear polymers often exhibit limited ion conductivity due to the inefficient distribution of ion exchange sites, which can reduce the overall system efficiency. Additionally, they are prone to mechanical degradation, especially under the high-stress conditions typical of AEMWE and AEMFC operations, leading to potential swelling, cracking, or mechanical failure [120]. Chemically, linear polymers may also suffer from poor stability in the harsh alkaline environments required for these applications, resulting in a reduced membrane lifespan. Furthermore, introducing additional functional groups to improve performance can be challenging, as the uniform structure of linear polymers offers limited scope for modification [121], which hampers overall efficiency. As a result, alternative approaches, such as incorporating morphologically advanced polymers such as hyperbranched polymers, are often necessary to address these limitations and enhance membrane performance in AEMWE and AEMFC applications. However, we acknowledge the recent significant advancements in linear AEMs for both AEMFC and AEMWE, which have demonstrated promising performance [122–139]. It is important to clarify that our approach does not suggest linear AEMs are unsuitable. Rather, we emphasize that while linear AEMs may pose certain challenges, our research is focused on exploring alternative architectures in parallel with ongoing developments in linear AEMs. Hyperbranched polymers are a specialized type of dendritic macromolecule, characterized by their highly branched three-dimensional structure as shown in Fig. 7 (a) [140]. These polymers have a degree of branching less than 1, which affects their solubility, viscosity, and thermal stability. Further they offer unique properties beneficial for mitigating these degradation mechanisms in AEM. They provide significant steric hindrance [141] around QA groups, protecting them from nucleophilic attacks and reducing the rate of elimination. The steric bulk of hyperbranched polymers makes it difficult for nucleophiles to access and attack QA groups, lowering the probability of nucleophilic substitution. The core structure, which can consist of a single molecule and the branching units, which feature multiple reactive sites, create a highly branched network, while the terminal groups determine the surface properties and potential applications. They possess unique characteristics, such as lower intrinsic viscosity compared to linear polymers of similar molecular weight, enhanced solubility in various solvents, and good thermal stability suitable for high-temperature applications [142]. Additionally, their specific properties can be customized based on the degree of branching and polymer backbone flexibility. However due to weak chain entanglement as shown in Fig. 7(b) [143], developing a membrane solely relying on hyperbranched polymer is a tedious process since it leads to a non-uniform structure, but fine tuning it by giving additional support such as blending or adding a structure, which can substitute the weak chain entanglement and to use in AEM will offer high ionic conductivity and chemical stability. Even though it is an emerging field of research, there are notable results in terms of its conductivity has been achieved by using hyperbranching and their structure responsible for achieving the allround performance has been depicted in Fig. 8 (a) of hyper-branched poly(triethyltriindolearyl piperidinium) [144], Fig. 8(b) of hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium) [145], Fig. 8(c) of hyperbranched poly(arylene ether ketone) [146], Fig. 8(d) of Tröger’s Base with hyperbranched structure [147], and Fig. 8(e) of hyperbranched poly(4-vinylbenzyl chloride) [148]. However, the methodology is not solely restricted to these structures alone, there are numerous polymer backbones that can be developed by adopting the commercially feasible methodology such as one pot synthesis. Also there are other backbone as shown in Fig. 8, which are having the possibility to develop AEM from or it can be used to optimize morphology in a composite AEM structure such as hyperbranched polysulfone [149] Fig. 9 (a) features a three-dimensional network of aromatic rings and sulfone groups, providing excellent thermal and chemical stability. The branching will increase ion exchange sites and water uptake which will enhance conductivity. This structure balances mechanical strength with improved functionality, making it ideal for AEM and hyperbranched poly(ethylene imine) (HPEI) [150]. Fig. 9(b) features a highly branched structure with numerous surface amine groups giving charge density, making it effective for ion exchange. While the amine groups can oxidize, it can remain chemically stable, especially when quaternized. Additionally, its hydrophilic nature can lead to significant water uptake, which could boost conductivity with careful control to avoid excessive swelling. Similarly hyperbranched polyamidoamine [151] in Fig. 9(c) with numerous branching provide abundance of amine groups, making it a promising candidate for AEM. Further, hyperbranched polyimide [152] in Fig. 9(d) with highly branched, three-dimensional network structure with imide linkages increases the surface area and introduces additional sites for functionalization and its backbone consists of aromatic rings, which contribute to the polymer's rigidity and thermal stability. Even though its hydrophilicity is low when compared to HPEI and polyamidoamine it could be overcomed by adding hydrophilic segments to create a microphase separation which will provide pathways for ion conduction, making it also suitable material for AEM. Given this, this review delves into the role of a few hyperbranched polymers employed in AEMFCs and potential for AEMWE. Generally, the hyperbranching in AEMs could be achieved through one-pot synthesis reactions [153]. With a facile optimization on synthesis approach, the polymers could be tuned with low viscosity, high solubility, and a diverse array of functional end-groups, making them suitable [154] for AEMWE. Their functionalization for AEMWE, involves the incorporation of positively charged moieties, to optimize the IEC and conductivities [155]. Despite the possible potential of hyperbranched polymers in WE applications, their development is still emerging, indicating the need for more progressive advancement. 3 Properties of hyperbranched polymers in AEMFC For an AEM to function effectively in both AEMFCs and AEMWE, it must exhibit a combination of critical properties as show in Fig. 10 . The membrane should absorb an optimal amount of water to ensure efficient ion conduction while minimizing swelling, which can compromise mechanical integrity. It must also maintain excellent stability in alkaline environments to ensure long-term durability and performance. Optimal mechanical properties are essential for the membrane to withstand physical stresses without tearing or deforming, while high thermal stability is necessary for operation at elevated temperatures without degradation. Additionally, the membrane must possess high ion conductivity and a good ion exchange capacity to facilitate efficient ion transport, which is vital for both power generation in fuel cells and hydrogen production in water electrolysis. 3.1 Chemical stability The chemical stability of AEMs determines their efficiency and long-term performance. Among different properties, water uptake (WU), swelling ratio (SR), alkaline and oxidative stability are of particular importance. The adequate WU of AEM facilitates the movement of OH– ions, which is vital for efficient ion diffusion. However, excessive WU causes over-swelling of the membrane that compromises the mechanical strength of the membrane. Hence, controlling the extent of swelling is important to maintain the mechanical integrity of the membrane and to prevent performance loss [156]. Furthermore, the alkaline stability of AEM is one of the crucial aspects as it ensures chemical endurance under high pH values to overcome degradation and maintains the IEC and structural integrity [157]. Stability towards oxidation is also important for fuel cell cathode and more importantly electrolyser anode. Conclusively, overcoming the above-mentioned properties of AEM is essential for ensuring the membrane's longevity and preventing performance loss. Given this, several strategies have been done on tuning the hyperbranched polymers to increase the efficiency and stability of the AEM as shown in Table 4 , which lists the hyperbranching moieties and their respective WU, SR, and alkaline stability values. 3.1.1 Impact of blending Polymer blending is a widely used method to optimize properties by combining polymers with complementary characteristics. This approach harnesses the unique advantages of each polymer to create a composite material with enhanced functionality, overcoming the inherent limitations of individual material. Through precise selection, blending improves key properties such as mechanical robustness, chemical resilience, and ionic conductivity. This methodology is especially advantageous in energy applications, where achieving a balance of structural integrity, processability, and performance is essential. Blending a linear polymer with a hyperbranched polymer offers a promising approach for creating a hybrid blend AEMs. The linear polymer provides structural integrity and mechanical strength, while the hyperbranched polymer, with its unique architecture and high density of functional groups, enhances ionic conductivity by increasing the availability and distribution of ion-exchange sites throughout the membrane. This combination could also improve dimensional stability by reducing swelling and increasing water retention, which are essential for maintaining performance under operational conditions. The synergistic effect of this blend may result in an AEM with superior conductivity, mechanical robustness, and long-term stability. Accordingly, Kim et al. [142] demonstrates the advantages of blending hyperbranched poly(arylene ether sulfone) (HB-PAES) with linear PPO (PPO-HB-PAES) to achieve a balance of stability, and microphase separation in AEMs. While PAES typically offers significant mechanical strength and thermal stability due to its linear aromatic backbone, its rigidity limits solubility and processability. However, the hyperbranched architecture of HB-PAES introduces terminal functional groups and branching points that improve solubility, flexibility, and stress distribution. When blended with PPO, which further contributes to structural strength, the resulting AEM shows enhanced WU and dimensional stability. The blend achieved WU between 34.6% and 50.3% at 90 °C, a result of the distinct microphase separation due to the aggregation of hydrophilic regions resulting from the electrostatic interaction (N+/OH−) and H-bonding interaction (OH−/H2O) between quaternized HB-PAES and PPO in Fig. 11 (AFM and 3D images) facilitating effective water retention without excessive swelling, as seen from the SR of 20.9% to 25.0% at 90 °C due to the dimensional stability offered by PPO, while the HB-PAES enhances ionic site and parallely shields functionality by steric hindrance which leads to retaining 85.3% of IEC after 1000 h in a high-pH environment. This synergy between HB-PAES and PPO highlights the effectiveness of polymer blends in optimizing both stability and phase separation for fuel cells and electrolysers. In addition to blending, adding crosslinking to the blend also yield sufficient stability as study by Cao et al. [121] reveals that incorporating hyperbranched poly(4-vinylbenzyl chloride) (HVBC) into PPO and crosslinking with N,N,N’,N’-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine (TMHDA), creates a robust membrane structure with enhanced properties in WU, SR, oxidative, and alkaline stability. The hyperbranched HVBC structure, rich in terminal CH2Cl groups and significant free volume (which the authors does not provide sufficient data or experiments details), promotes hydrophilicity and improves conductivity by accommodating water molecules without causing excessive swelling. This controlled swelling behavior, attributed to HVBC’s three-dimensional ionic network and loosely crosslinked framework Fig. 12 (a and b), achieves a high WU of 132.31% and an SR of 25.71 at 80 °C about 3.2 times that of unmodified PPO. The blend demonstrated strong oxidative and alkaline stability, showing minimal degradation even under harsh conditions, suggest that the combination of PPO’s structural stability and HVBC’s functional adaptability creates a balanced membrane with both effective ion transport and resilience in oxidative stability in Fenton’s reagent at 60 °C, retained 95% of their weight over 24 h, with less than 15% weight loss after 30 days and in alkaline environments retaining 50% of conductivity after 600 h in NaOH at 60 °C. This synergy points to the potential of hyperbranched blends in achieving durability and performance standards necessary for applications like fuel cells and electrolysers. Overall, blending linear and hyperbranched polymers and adding crosslinking has proven effective in enhancing AEM stability, combining the WU and SR. Despite these advancements, achieving long-term durability under harsh operational conditions remains challenging. To enhance the resilience of blended AEMs, research should focus on strategies that ensure sustained phase stability, such as optimizing polymer compatibility or employing advanced cross-linking methods. Such efforts will maximize the functional benefits of blended AEMs in fuel cell and electrolysers. 3.1.2 Impact of structural functionalisation In AEMs, structural functionalisation is essential for balancing ion transport efficiency with membrane stability. This process involves targeted modifications to the polymer backbone or the incorporation of specific functional groups, such as QA sites, to significantly enhance ionic conductivity while carefully controlling WU and swelling. Achieving this balance is crucial to develop high-performance AEMs capable of withstanding the rigorous demands of applications like fuel cells and electrolysers. Structural functionalisation thus supports the creation of resilient membranes, ensuring effective ion transport pathways while maintaining the mechanical integrity required for long-term operational stability. Achieving optimal AEM performance requires a careful balance between sufficient WU for effective ion transport and maintaining structural stability to prevent excessive swelling. Effective structural functionalization, such as that achieved by Ge et al. [158] using a hyperbranched polymer with QA sites, exemplifies this approach. By synthesizing HB-PVBC with ATRP and then quaternizing with N,N,N',N',N''-pentamethyl diethylenetriamine (PMDETA), the structure maximized ionic site density Fig. 12(c) while controlling water absorption.The hyperbranched architecture of HB-PVBC provides a high density of QA sites, essential for efficient OH− transport. The incorporation of PMDETA, featuring a diethylenetriamine backbone with methyl groups attached to its nitrogen atoms was used a quaternization agent. This structure confers high nucleophilicity and basicity, as the nitrogen atoms are highly reactive due to their lone pairs of electrons and the electron donating effect of the methyl groups. Additionally, the robust carbon–nitrogen bonds and stable diethylenetriamine backbone allowing for robust performance even at elevated temperatures. As a result, the membrane achieved a controlled WU of less than 45 wt% and a linear SR below 16% at 80 °C, preventing excessive swelling that can compromise mechanical integrity. In comparative tests Fig. 12(d and e), this structure maintained flexibility and transparency after 20 days in 1 M NaOH at 80 °C, underscoring its high alkaline stability a result of the densely packed QA network that shields the polymer backbone from degradation. On the other hand, microphase separation, an important parameter in membrane morphology plays a key role in maintaining chemical stability, water swelling ratio and increased conductivity. It is characterized by the formation of distinct nanoscale domains, typically comprising hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments that segregate and self-assemble into well-defined structures. The hydrophobic domains serve as protective barriers, a mechanism known as the barrier effect [159], which shields the hydrophilic segments from chemical degradation by limiting the penetration of reactive species. This segregation contributes to a controlled water swelling ratio, as the hydrophobic domains restrict excessive swelling in the hydrophilic regions, thereby maintaining structural integrity and preventing material failure. Furthermore, the hydrophilic domains create continuous ion-conductive pathways that facilitate efficient ion transport, thereby enhancing overall ionic conductivity. The optimal hydration within these domains ensures high ion mobility without diluting the ion concentration or disrupting the conductive network. By providing a synergistic combination of chemical stability, controlled swelling, and increased conductivity, microphase-separated morphology plays a vital role in applications such as water electrolysers. Even though some observations verify the creation of distinct OH− transporting domains [160], the overall performance of linear AEMs, including their conductivity, mechanical properties, and alkaline stability, still facing difficulties to meet the commercial requirements. These deficiencies are largely due to the limitations imposed by the linear polymer backbone in membrane morphology structure in existing AEMs. Subsequently on examining the microphase separation, Ge et al. [161] revealed that how the chain length of diamine crosslinkers in hyperbranched AEMs affects microphase separation WU, SR and alkaline stability. They found moderate chain length provides the optimal balance in chemical stability by cross-linking HB-PVBC with N,N,N',N'-tetramethyl ethylene diamine (TEMEDA) with two carbon (2-C), N, N,N',N'-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine (TEMHDA) (6-C), N,N,N',N'-Tetramethyl-1,10-decyldiamine TEMDDA (HBM-10C). TEMEDA with its short ethylene backbone, is a highly flexible and reactive molecule due to its strong nucleophilicity and high basicity results in a rapid crosslinking reaction and the formation of a dense structure shows limited WU to 16.35 wt% and swelling to 6.18% in-plane LSR, yet the compact structure lacks distinct hydrophilic-hydrophobic domains, limiting ionic pathwaysc Fig. 13 (a). TEMHDA (HBM-6C), featuring a hexamethylene backbone, strikes a balance between flexibility and rigidity. Its moderate chain length forms a more flexible crosslinked network compared to TEMDDA, achieves an optimal balance of properties, showing moderate WU (81.13 wt%) and controlled swelling (5.38% LSR), as well as well-defined 3 nm hydrophilic domains that create efficient ion channels Fig. 13(a) and maintaining conductivity after 10 days in 2 M NaOH at 60 °C. TEMDDA (HBM-10C), with a long decamethylene backbone, provides significant flexibility and hydrophobic character. Although the steric hindrance around its amine groups may slow the crosslinking reaction, it forms a highly flexible and less dense network forms a looser structure Fig. 13(b and c) that absorbs excessive water (237.76 wt% at 60 °C) and has significant swelling (10.96% LSR), leading to larger, scattered hydrophilic domains (7.5 nm) that disrupt ion pathways, suffered from severe water swelling, resulting in mechanical failure after post treatment with 2 M NaOH at 60 °C for 10 days. These observations highlight that the chain length of diamine crosslinkers in hyperbranched AEMs significantly influences microphase separation, WU, swelling behavior, and alkaline stability. A moderate chain length provides an optimal structure that balances these properties, enabling efficient ion transport and mechanical resilience, which are critical for durable membrane performance under alkaline conditions. Since these crosslinking approaches yield notable results, to verify high cation density with crosslinking which can result in AEMs with both high ionic conductivity and reduced water swelling, crosslinked HB-PVBC with poly(N, N-dimethylbenzylamine) P(DMBA) defined here as ((HB-PVBC)-P(DMBA)) was further studied by Zhu et al. [148] and it is proven to be effective strategy as crosslinked structure creates a stable, interconnected network that prevents excessive WU while establishing hydrated pathways as P(DMBA) posses lone pairs on the nitrogen atoms that facilitate effective ion interaction for ion conduction and achieves a controlled WU of 46.1% and a low SR of 3.2% at 80 °C due to the crosslinked structure and well-developed microphase-separated morphology. Moreover this approach also reflected on alkaline stability as this design omits β-hydrogens near quaternary ammonium groups, preventing Hofmann elimination and allowing degradation mainly through nucleophilic substitution at the β-carbon. This stability is further supported by hydrophilic-hydrophobic separation and crosslinking, which confine OH− ions to hydrophilic areas, shielding the aromatic backbone which leads to alkaline stability for 10 days in 1 M NaOH solution at 60 °C showed chloride conductivity of C-HBM-1.78 remained at 22.5 mS cm−1 at 30 °C and retained 72% IEC from its initial value. This method shows strong potential for developing high-efficiency AEMs with controlled water uptake with SR and improved alkaline stability. On the other hand distribution of pyrrolidinium cations and the length of poly(methyldiallylamine) (PMDA) chains in hyperbranched poly(vinylbenzyl chloride) (HB-PVBC) membranes have demonstrated significant potential in alkaline stability and hydration pattern for AEMFC applications. Longer PMDA chains create a well-defined microphase-separated morphology, enhanced by crosslinking, which resists excessive water absorption and supports stable ion transport and alkaline stability due to β-proton in the non-antiperiplanar position,which conformationally disfavored Hofmann elimination. Also it is noteworthy that β-hydrogens (protons on the carbon adjacent to the cationic center) are key players in determining whether or not elimination can occur. For Hofmann elimination to proceed efficiently, the β-proton must be in an antiperiplanar position relative to the leaving group. This antiperiplanar alignment allows for an ideal geometric orientation that promotes the elimination reaction, leading to the formation of a double bond.When the β-proton is in a non-antiperiplanar position (meaning it is not directly opposite to the leaving group in the molecular structure), this orientation does not favor Hofmann elimination. In this non-antiperiplanar arrangement, the geometry hinders the alignment necessary for the elimination reaction, making it energetically less favorable and suppressing Hofmann degradation. This study by Duan et al. [162] examined the impact of PMDA with two different chain length with series of IEC, finding that longer chains HBM-Py2 with number average molecular weight 30.7 kg mol−1 produced a more defined microphase-separated morphology compared to shorter chains HBM-Py1 with number average molecular weight 15.6 kg mol−1 as observed through TEM Fig. 14 (a–c) and SAXS analysis Fig. 14(d–f) reveals that organized phase separation, indicated by distinct peaks in longer PMDA chains, as in HBM-Py2-1.62, show clear SAXS peaks, and further, higher IECs narrow the SAXS peak, reflecting more pronounced phase separation supported by the spacing between nanophase-separated domains (d) 24.0 and 33.4 nm. In contrast, shorter chains in HBM-Py1-1.60 lack SAXS peaks, leading to increased WU and SR, underscoring the need for defined phase separation in stable AEM. Additionally, the membranes showed considerable stability in alkaline environments, retaining high conductivity and IEC values under harsh conditions. Specifically, membrane HBM-Py2-1.62 retained up to 80% of its initial chloride conductivity and IEC after 10 days in 4 M NaOH at 60 °C. The findings demonstrate that hyperbranched AEMs with carefully regulated molecular architecture offer a feasible route to develop better alkaline stable AEM. Although crosslinking hyperbranched polymers is a viable method for creating AEMs, it faces significant challenges and requires careful control over membrane fabrication. A RAFT polymerization protocol proposed by Liu et al. [143] which involves incorporating soft segments to enhance chain entanglement in hyperbranched AEMs represents a promising strategy which allows for better control of the quaternization process but also facilitates the formation of more efficient hydroxide conductive channels. Importantly, it helps to maintain suppressed water swelling, even at elevated temperatures and post-processing solvent annealing induce an ordered morphology within the membrane. They synthesized hyperbranched polystyrene (HPS) via RAFT polymerization using S-(4-vinyl) benzyl S’-propyltrithiocarbonate (VBPT) as the initiator. HPS served as a macromolecular chain transfer agent to graft vinyl benzyl chloride (VBC) segments, forming HPSV. However, futher attempts to crosslink with diamine yield produce a yellowish AEM Fig. 15 (a) yet controlling the process at elevated temperatures was difficult and alternatively, hyperbranched PVBC (HPV) was synthesized via VBPT-initiated RAFT polymerization and used to initiate isoprene polymerization, forming HPVI which was easily dissolvable in NMP and produced a free-standing, flexible, and transparent membrane as seen from Fig. 15(b) and quaternized with triethylamine yielded hyperbranched poly(vinyl benzyl chloride)-b-polyisoprene (QHPVI) membrane exhibiting superior WU of 38.6% up to 51.2% from 30 to 80 °C, yet the linear SR remains unchanged at 36.3 wt% at 80 °C due to flexible hydrophobic shell (PI segments) and tough hydrophilic core (QHPV segments) which host water molecules while maintaining the dimensional stability and the membrane showed self assembly with hydrohilic and hydrophilic segments as alternating ridges and valleys patterns as seen surface SEM images from Fig. 15(c and d) and further annealing with chloroform vapor induces the aggregation of ionic segments benefical for ionic conduction Fig. 15(e and f). Addtionally the membranes conductivity remained unchanged 1 M NaOH solution at 80 °C for 10 days demonstrating excellent chemical stability yet there is no clear detail for its chemical stability by the author. These finding suggest alternative approach other than crosslinking also yeileds a commandable results in hyperbranched architecture. Alternatively, Lin et al. [163] reported that TB-based polymer AEMs exhibit excellent alkaline stability, showing only minor decreases in IEC and OH− conductivity after extended stability testing, underscoring their robustness in alkaline environments. These findings suggest that TB-based polymers orderly arrangement with hydrophilic/hydrophobic microphase separation, thereby improving OH− conductivity and limiting the SR. However they still suffered by their poor mechanical properties and low solubility and here comes the advantages of hyperbranched architecture which can improve the solubility and gets complemented for its low entanglement [164]. Accordingly, Chen et al. [147] introduced a hyperbranched architecture into TB-based AEMs to enhance ion conductivity and stability by using 2,4,6-Tris(4-aminophenyl)-s-triazine (TAPT 0% to 8%), as a branching agent with its stable triazine core and three 4-aminophenyl groups, offers multiple branching sites that promote crosslinking without excessive rigidity and TB-based hyperbranched AEM membranes exhibited enhanced WU due to the additional free volume created by the branched structure,at the same time maintaining SR, creating efficient ion-conducting pathways and ionic cluster formation with sufficient alkaline stability. Here the authors measured the free volume using BET surface area measurements and it is noteworthy to mention that BET surface area measurements provide indirect evidence of free volume by quantifying the internal porosity of a material. An increased BET surface area, as seen in QA-BTB-5% (54.7 m2 g−1) compared to QA-TB (34.3 m2 g−1), suggests more accessible internal voids, attributed to the introduction of a branching agent. While BET does not directly measure free volume, the increased porosity implies an enhanced free volume within the structure, allowing more water retention and promotes microphase separation. Specifically, the WU and SR increased from 35.4% to 57.6% at 30 °C and from 41.7% to 62.6% at 80 °C as while SR increases from 8.3% to 16.6% at 30 °C and from 11.1% to 20.8% at 80 °C. The enhanced WU and reasonable SR values are attributed to the microphase separation structure of QA-TB and QA-BTB-5% which was examined using TEM, as illustrated in Fig. 16 (a and b) and AFM images Fig. 16(c and d) further support this observation, showing larger dark hydrophilic domains in QA-BTB-5% and SAXS analysis shows a distinct peak for QA-BTB-5% at 2.62 nm−1, indicating good ion cluster aggregation with an average interdomain spacing of 2.40 nm using Bragg’s equation Fig. 16(e). In addition, the bulky rigid branched structures Fig. 16(f) weakened the attacked of OH− to the cation groups due to steric hindrance resulted in a alkaline stability at 80 °C for 20 days in 1 M NaOH. These approach validate that introducing hyperbranched structures increases free volume, promoting microphase separation and boosts alkaline stability. On the other hand tethering the flexible spacers in hyperbranched architecture also yield promising results Yang et al. [146], shows that how dense ionic groups and lengthening flexible spacer between the cationic groups and backbone enhancing ion cluster domain formation and chemical stability, since the hyperbranched architecture introduces multiple branching points providing numerous functional end groups which will be quaternised and the presence of ketone groups enhances the polymer's polarity and chemical resistance through electron-withdrawing effects, stabilizing the backbone against nucleophilic attack and oxidation. Here they synthesized the hyperbranched poly(arylene ether ketone) (HBPAEK) AEM using 1-(N′,N′-dimethylamino)-6,12-(N,N,N-trimethyl ammonium) dodecane bromide (BQA) by varying the hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments (HBPAEK-x-18), in which x (x = 5, 9, 21, 28) represents hydrophilic and 18 indicates hydrophobic segments and the membranes exhibited distinct hydrophilic darker regions/hydrophobic brighter regions phase separation Fig. 16(g–j). Further the peak intensity from SAXS analysis increasing alongside the length of the hydrophilic segment Fig. 17 (a) and corresponding interdomain spacings (6.47, 9.96, 10.64, and 17.94 nm) from Bragg's law (d = 2π/qmax), indicates that increasing the hydrophilic block length enlarges the hydrophilic domain size, as confirmed by the TEM images which leads to WU of 17.1% to 58.6% at 80 °C, and SR ranging from 16.5% to 41.8% and demonstrating strong alkaline stability, the HBPAEK-28–18 membrane with its expanded hydrophilic domains retains 84% of its cationic groups after 500 h in 2 M KOH at 80 °C Fig. 17(b) since minimal degradation is observed in 1H NMR results Fig. 17(c) showing a slight decrease in the integral area of peaks associated with BQA methyl protons, while the chemical structure remains largely intact, underscoring the membrane's resilience in high-pH conditions. This study suggests that expanded hydrophilic domains and a stable chemical backbone are key for enhancing both ion transport channel and durability in alkaline environments. While exploring the potential of different approach, it has been reported that increasing molecular spacing and reducing intermolecular interactions through the introduction of side chains in AEMs effectively enhances FFV, which lowers resistance to ion transport and improves ionic conductivity. This effect is particularly prominent in branched AEMs, where weaker chain entanglement and larger interchain distances create more accessible ion pathways. However, in hyperbranched polymers, the higher degree of branching further amplifies FFV, leading to looser chain packing and increased interchain distances, which together promote efficient ion movement and enhance membrane conductivity as stated by Yuan et al. [145]. Accordingly they [145] have synthesized a series of hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium) AEMs (B-TPP-x) with different molar ratio of 1,3,5-triacetylbenzene as the branching point and shows that WU increased with rising temperature, attributed to enhanced mobility of polymer chain, yet maintaining a balance in SR essential which can weaken mechanical stability due to hyperbranched structures which creates FFV that accommodates water without significant swelling. Here the free volume is not accurately measured and the authors quoted that dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) showed that hyperbranched AEM (B-TPP-x) exhibited a lower Tg compared to the linear AEM (TPP), suggesting that B-TPP-x possessed more FFVs than TPP and explained that this signified weak entanglement of chain segments in the hyperbranched AEM, resulting in increased FFV. Specifically WU of membranes varied between 89% and 98%, and the swelling ratio drastically reduced from 123% to 9% when increasing the branching from 10% to 40%, due to loosen chain entanglement facilitating a high FFV and distinct phase separation from AFM images Fig. 18 (a–e) highlighting the hydrophobic (blue) and hydrophilic (yellow) phase domains of the AEM where hydrophilic domains in the linear AEM from Fig. 18(a) showed a significantly less uniform distribution compared to those in the hyperbranched AEM (B-TPP-x) from Fig. 18(b–e). However a gradually decrease in WU and SR with higher degrees of branching which limits the number of accessible ion exchange sites, leads to fewer hydrophilic sites that attract and hold water molecules, resulting in lower WU. Moreover, the ether-bond-free aryl backbone and piperidine ring exhibited strong resistance to OH− attack, contributing to B-TPP-10% minimal conductivity loss in 1 M KOH at 80 °C over the initial 2000 h attributed to the structural rigidity and steric hindrance. However, after 2600 h, 1H NMR spectra showed new olefinic proton peaks, suggesting Hoffmann elimination and indicating that oxidative degradation, likely via a free radical mechanism, led to further conductivity loss beyond 2000 h. The study suggests that hyperbranched structures in AEMs enhance FFV, promoting efficient ion transport. However, while they improve water uptake and stability initially, prolonged exposure under alkaline conditions may lead to degradation due to Hofmann elimination and oxidative mechanisms which needs to be improvised while applying in AEM electrolyser since this approach yield promising results. In addition to free volume and branching degree, localized stacking also plays a defining role in balancing rigidity and free volume, creating efficient ion pathways and enhancing durability under alkaline conditions. Ma et al. [144] reported straightforward method to prepare hyperbranched poly(triethyltriindolearyl piperidinium) (hb-QPTP) AEMs, featuring a three-dimensional architecture with triethyltriindole (TTI) as a branching point. They have analysed FFV using molecular dynamics and Tg from DMA and found that introducing the bulky, π-conjugated aromatic heterocyclic TTI into hyperbranched polymers has opposing effects on Tg and FFV. While TTI typically raises Tg by restricting the polymer chain's flexibility, the hyperbranched structure simultaneously increases FFV, which can lower Tg. This expanded FFV, resulting from the loosely packed, three-dimensional network, facilitates ion movement within the polymer matrix. As the TTI content increases, FFV rises, offsetting the rigidity effect on Tg, leading to a moderate decrease in Tg as observed experimentally where hb-QPTPX and QPTP exhibited different FFV values of 33.2%–38.6% and 29.3%, respectively. This balance between rigidity and free volume enhances ion transport, as confirmed by distinct phase separation observed in TEM images (Fig. 18f and g), where dark regions correspond to hydrophilic phases (ionic groups) and bright regions represent hydrophobic phases. Large ionic clusters, with a diffraction peak at q = 3.6 nm−1 from SAXS (Fig. 18h), along with effective localized stacking, provide WU ranging from 55.3% to 88.4% as the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C, suitable for balanced hydrated ion transportation and the SR remained low, between 11.53% and 18.3%, and was almost constant across varying temperatures. Furthermore, the bulky TTI monomer near cationic sites adds steric hindrance, minimizing hydroxide attack; after 2000 h in 1 M KOH at 80 °C, the membrane retained over 92% hydroxide conductivity, with minimal β-H degradation in piperidinium groups (about 10%) and only a slight 9.5% reduction in tensile strength which indicates that degradation was limited to the cationic groups while the backbone remained stable. This finding highlights that incorporating bulky branching points in hyperbranched AEMs increases FFV, supporting efficient ion transport and enhancing alkaline stability. Overall chemical stability in AEMs can be achieved by synergistically combining linear and hyperbranched polymers, crosslinking hyperbranched structures, and optimizing the branching ratio along with FFV. Integrating linear with hyperbranched polymers enhances ion transport while maintaining mechanical integrity. Crosslinking hyperbranched structures significantly improves dimensional stability and chemical resistance, reducing membrane swelling and degradation in alkaline environments. Modifying the branching ratio with FFV adjustments allows for higher IEC and improved conductivity. Compared to blending approaches, structural functionalization offers more robust results, broadening the scope for developing AEMs with enhanced chemical stability, making it as a promising direction for applications in AEMWE and AEMFC. 3.2 Mechanical and thermal stability The mechanical and thermal properties of AEMs are critical factors, since maintaining high mechanical strength is essential for ensuring the structural integrity and durability of AEMWE and AEMFC. Mechanical robustness prevents membrane deformation, tearing, and degradation, extending the operational lifespan and reliability of AEMWE [165,166]. Ensuring optimal tensile strength (TS) and elongation at break (EB) is crucial to prevent failures that could compromise efficiency. However, while tensile strength is a vital factor, it is equally important for the material to possess good toughness. Toughness, the capacity of a material to absorb energy and deform plastically before fracturing, is crucial in dynamic environments with sudden forces or deformations. A tougher material can withstand impact and bending stresses without cracking or failing, thus protecting the substrate and preserving its functionality. Although rigid polymer backbones provide substantial mechanical strength, they often have limited flexibility (elongation at break). This induces brittleness in AEM, especially under low humidity, which poses challenges to membrane electrode assembly fabrication and long-term cell operation.
