However, incorporating flexible structures into rigid AEMs can mitigate brittleness by increasing the elongation at break and enhancing toughness [167]. While using membrane supports like PTFE porous film [168] as a support enhances mechanical properties, it may introduce compatibility issues and reduce conductivity due to tortuous hydroxide ion conduction paths. On the other hand thermal stability is essential to enduring fluctuating and high temperatures without compromising the structural and functional integrity to maintain consistent performance and efficiency [169]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed to study the degradation temperature (T d) of polymer backbone and cationic functional groups. In addition, the interplay between mechanical properties and thermal stability is crucial as the AEMs that exhibit both high mechanical strength and thermal stability are more likely to withstand the demanding conditions of AEMWE and AEMFC, ensuring efficient and long-term operation. Hyperbranching of AEM has shown significant advancement in providing the essential mechanical and thermal properties for long-term operations as Table 5 , shows the mechanical properties of several hyperbranched membranes used in the AEM. 3.2.1 Impact of blending On evaluating mechanical and thermal stability in blending aspects, it shows substantial enhancement in mechanical properties. Specifically (PPO-HB-PVBC) [121], blends exhibit improved mechanical interlocking due to the inclusion of hyperbranched VBC. This mechanical interlocking effect significantly enhances resistance to deformation, yielding TS values ranging from 17.34 to 32.33 MPa (Table 5). These values closely align with those of commercial Fumatech FAA-3–30 and FAA-3–50 membranes (Table 2), highlighting the maximum stress these blended membranes can endure before breaking. Moreover, EB values between 20.4% and 43.1%, comparable to commercial membranes Fumatech FAA-3–30 and FAA-3–50, indicate that the crosslinked and loosely packed structural configuration improves the membrane’s ability to undergo significant deformation before rupture. This flexibility is critical as it ensures membrane durability under operational stress, underscoring that the blend possesses free volume within the polymer matrix, which, in turn, facilitates the polymer chains' flexibility. Comparatively, PPO-HB-PVBC membranes are found to be superior to the HBPAEK [146] with dense ionic groups and long flexible spacers between the cationic groups and backbone which offers the highest TS value of 30.8 MPa, and EB value of 17.4% as tabulated in Table 5. The linear PPO provides a stable and strong framework, while the HB-PVBC offers a high density of reactive sites, resulting in a well-balanced combination of strength and flexibility. Addtionally the PPO-HB-PVBC blends exhibit enhanced thermal stability compared to the pristine PPO-Cr membranes with lack of significant weight loss below 200 °C which shows their suitability for fuel cells and eletrolysers. On the other hand, while the mechanical property was not explicitly mentioned, the thermal properties of the blended (PPO-HB-PAES) [142], were evaluated using TGA Fig. 19 (a). The blend combines steric protection and backbone rigidity, enhancing its thermal stability as HB-PAES provides steric hindrance, shielding QA sites, while PPO adds rigidity, resisting thermal degradation. Three stages thermal degradation reveals water release at 135 °C supports ionic conductivity, QA decomposition between 180 and 400 °C sustains ion transport, and backbone breakdown above 400 °C highlights structural resilience. This stability profile makes the HB-PAES/PPO blend a promising candidate for high-performance AEMs in fuel cells and electrolysers. Blending in AEMs significantly enhances both mechanical and thermal properties by promoting strong interlocking within the polymer matrix, which boosts resistance to deformation and provides an ideal balance of strength and flexibility making these AEMs well-suited for high-performance applications in fuel cells and electrolysers. 3.2.2 Impact of structural fucntionalisation On evaluating effect of structural functionalization in mechanical and themal property, hyperbranched AEM(HB-PVBC-PMDETA) [158] with a denser network shows TS of 14.97 MPa and EB of 4.77% (Table 5) and multi-stage degradation profile from TGA analysis (128–524 °C) provide a satisfactory requirement for membrane electrode assembly in a fuel cell, however it is found to be lower than PPO-HB-PVBC [121] and HPAEK [146] due to its less rigid structure and lower crosslinking density. PPO-HB-PVBC benefits from a stable PPO backbone and dense ionic sites, providing strong internal bonding and enhanced stability. HPAEK’s ether-ketone linkages and aromatic rings contribute to its high thermal resistance and mechanical strength. On the other hand, (HB-PVBC)-Diamine [161] found that variation in diamine chain length in crosslinkers plays a critical role in mechanical integrity of hyperbranched AEMs, specifically medium-chain crosslinkers (HBM-6C), achieve an optimal microphase-separated morphology with interconnected hydrophilic channels, maintaining structural integrity. This balance is evidenced by good mechanical strength (TS of 10.19 MPa, EB of 5.76%) with moderate WU and controlled swelling rendering its suitability for AEMFC. However short-chain even though shows higher TS than medium chain, due to compact structure which was beneficial for mechanical integrity but does not give beneficial effect on ionic pathways and shows inhibiting effect. On the other hand, long chain with (HBM-10C) while improving ionic pathways tends absorb more water loosely crosslinked packed and exhibits mechanical failure. These suggest that how well the chain length play a critical role in maintaining a mechanical integrity. On the contrary TGA results demonstrates that all hyperbranched AEMs exhibit considerable thermal stability across chain lengths. Similarly to facilitate crosslinking with dense functionalization results shows that mechanical stability is not improved HB-PVBC-P(DMBA) [148] (Table 5) even though offers a promising approach to achieving high ionic content in AEMs. However, there is a trade-off between ionic content and mechanical robustness since the rigidity of the HB-PVBC structure combined with the multiamine crosslinking agent, which enhances dimensional stability and reduces swelling but contributes to reduced tensile strength. In the fully hydrated state, C-HBM-1.27 demonstrates a TS of 13.37 MPa and EB of 3.31%. With increased quaternization to enhance the IEC, the TS of the resulting C-HBM-1.78 membrane experiences a slight decrease to 12.37 MPa, while the EB increases to 5.20% due to plasticizing effect of water yet the membrane remains stable up to 218 °C as shown in Fig. 19(b), making it suitable for fuel cell applications typically operating in the 60–80 °C range. These findings reinforce that while crosslinking with high-density functionalization improves ionic conductivity and thermal stability, further research is necessary to enhance mechanical stability. In addition to the chain length of crosslinking agents influences the mechanical properties, their distribution in the membrane also plays a key role where higher crosslinking density typically strengthens TS by creating a more rigid structure, at the expense of flexibility, while lower crosslinking density enhances Eb but may reduce mechanical strength as reported by HB-PVBC-Poly(methyldiallylamine) [162]. Shorter chains, such as in HBM-Py1, increase EB but decrease TS, indicating a more flexible structure (EB 10.69%, TS 22.85 MPa). In contrast, longer chains enhance TS but reduce EB, resulting in a stiffer framework (EB 3.48%,TS 36.56 MPa). Higher IECs improve both flexibility and strength, as seen in HBM-Py2 membranes (HBM-Py2-2.18-TS 32.95 MPa, EB 5.30%), which achieve an optimal balance between durability and flexibility (Fig. 19c), which is in contrast to the HB-PVBC-P(DMBA) membrane where increase in IEC decrease TS. Additionally, TGA confirms that these membranes withstand temperatures well beyond typical operating conditions (80–100 °C), highlighting their resilience under thermal stress (Fig. 19d). This balance underscores the importance of precise control over polymer architecture to meet the demanding requirements of AEMFCs. In addition, adding flexible segments into hyperbranched PVBC (QHPVI)) [143] results in a low TS value of 6.77 MPa and EB value of 4.48% which is even though not appreciable yet it will helps to withstand the electrode assembly deformation due to optimal EB% and TGA results showed the effectiveness of QHPVI’s thermal stability in AEMFC as the degradation profile shows from 200 to 420 °C. On the other hand introducing a hyperbranched architectrure into a Trögers based structure QA-BTB [147] eventhough shows morphological advantages, its shows a trade-off with mechanical properties, specifically with TS and EB. This occurs because higher WU, facilitated by the increased free volume from branching, leads to a plasticization effect where the water molecules disrupt intermolecular forces within the polymer, reducing the polymer's rigidity. As an example, QA-BTB with TAPT showed a decrease in TS from 23.97 to 12.44 MPa and in EB from 12.26% to 9.03% (as seen in Table 5 and Fig. 19e) as the TAPT content increased. However, thermal stability remains high due to the rigid Tröger’s base backbone, which provides resilience at elevated temperatures essential for AEMWE and AEMFC applications. For instance, TGA data for branched QA-TB show two main weight loss stages: an initial loss at 280 °C and a significant polymer degradation step at 459 °C, reflecting the stability of the Tröger’s base (Fig. 19f). These suggest that while the intended purpose of improving the mechanical property by incorporating hyperbranched architecture is not attained and still required further research on Tröger’s base. On the other hand, Yuan et al. [145] highlights hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium) AEMs with 1,3,5-triacetylbenzene (B-TPP-x) exhibit excellent combination of thermal and mechanical stability, specifically the observed weight loss between 150 and 450 °C starts with cation shedding and main chain degradation validate the membrane's robust thermal stability. Further rigid, ether-free aryl backbone and piperidine ring, ensure structural resilience since B-TPP-x AEMs show TS between 26.2 and 32.3 MPa and EB from 22.8% to 29.0% under full hydration Table 5. These findings emphasize the importance of combining thermal and mechanical resilience in AEMs, particularly through rigid, ether-free structures, to ensure durability in fuel cell and electrolyser applications. Similarly Ma et al. [144] observed that although high branching in hyperbranched AEMs may reduce mechanical strength, the addition of localized stacking and rigid TTI groups in hb-QPTPX effectively maintained stability. Even with a lower molecular weight than its linear counterpart QPTP, hyperbranched structures (hb-QPTPX) demonstrated comparable tensile strength in dry conditions, thanks to the structural reinforcement provided by TTI. In wet conditions, however, the higher free volume in hb-QPTPX increased WU, leading to reduced strength due to water's plasticizing effect. Nonetheless, hb-QPTP10 AEM achieved an adequate tensile strength of 24.2 MPa and EB was varied between 18.6% and 25.2% in Table 5. Furthermore, the balance between FFV and IEC indicated that FFV had a stronger impact on mechanical stability, as increased branching lowered strength. Thermal stability tests confirmed that hb-QPTP AEMs maintain structural integrity well above operational temperatures, supporting their viability for electrolyser and fuel applications. Conclusively, blending linear polymers with hyperbranched polymers, along with stable cationic groups and crosslinkers, improves the mechanical properties of AEMs. Linear polymers provide mechanical strength, while hyperbranched polymers offer flexibility and increased ionic conductivity. Crosslinkers form a three-dimensional network that enhances durability and resists deformation. Fine-tuning the branching ratio is critical to balance crosslink density and polymer flexibility, ensuring significant reinforcement without sacrificing flexibility leading to mechanical robustness and thermally stability in AEMWE and AEMFC. 3.3 Ion exchange capacity and conductivity The efficiency and long-term performance of AEMWE and AEMFC are known to be critically dependent on the IEC and ionic conductivity, which dictates the effective ion transport. IEC measures the number of exchangeable ions that the membrane can accommodate and is crucial for facilitating effective ion diffusion between the electrodes [170]. A high IEC is vital for the efficient transport of OH− ions in AEMFC and stable performance of the water-splitting reaction for hydrogen production in AEMWE [171]. Similarly, the ionic conductivity of the AEM is defined as the ability of the membrane to conduct OH− ions through its structure, which ensures efficient ion transport, with reduced internal resistance. Overall, the interplay between IEC and ionic conductivity is crucial for the optimal performance of fuel cell and electrolysers [172]. The AEMs exhibiting both high IEC and high ionic conductivity support efficient ion transport, essential for maintaining fast ion flux at low potential difference and sustaining the electrochemical reactions in stacks. Given this, hyperbranched polymers have the potential to significantly enhance the IEC and conductivity of AEMs without compromising to the physical and chemical stress in operating conditions. Furthermore, the unique structural arrangement increases the surface area and facilitates ion transport, leading to improved performance. Such characteristics of hyperbranched polymers exhibiting structural engineering, tuning, and optimization make them highly desired. Using simple chemistry, the architecture of hyperbranched polymers could be optimized and fine-tuned to superior IEC and conductivity as Table 6 presents the IEC and conductivity of the recently reported hyperbranched AEM. 3.3.1 Impact of blending Blending hyperbranched with linear polymers does not restrict improvements to chemical and mechanical properties but shown promising improvements in conductivity at a given IEC by providing continuous ion-conducting channels, essential for high conductivity. (PPO-HB-PAES) [142] combination of linear PPO and hyperbranched HB-PAES polymers creates a structure that balances durability with enhanced ion transport promoting well-defined pathways for ion conduction through microphase separation which facilitate smooth ion movement and Arrhenius plots of the pristine and blended membranes show activation energy (E a) values ranging from 8.03 to 12.80 kJ mol−1, indicating a vehicle mechanism of ion transport, where ions travel through hydrated pathways. This structural synergy enables the membranes to achieve high ion exchange capacities, reaching up to 1.97 mmol g−1, and impressive conductivity, with the 50:50 PPO-HB-PAES blend exhibiting a hydroxide ion conductivity of 90.9 mS cm−1 at 90 °C Fig. 20 (a) which is found to be higher than the commercially available AEMs listed in Table 2. Since, the principle of AEM conductivity lies in optimising both ionic group density and the structural pathways for ion transport, it was effectively demonstrated in PPO-HVBC blend [121] where the inclusion of HVBC significantly enhances IEC and thus conductivity, without compromising mechanical integrity. Higher HVBC content, facilitates greater quaternization, providing densely packed ionic sites essential for efficient ion transport. For example, with an IEC of 1.88 mmol g−1, PPO-HVBC achieves a conductivity of 135.9 mS cm−1 at 80 °C, outperforming many commercial and comparable membranes. Structural design of the blend, which forms a fast and wide anion transport pathway leverages high-density QA sites and the inherent free volume in the membrane matrix, enhancing ionic mobility. The blend’s activation energy for conductivity remains low, signifying reduced energy requirements for OH− transport an attribute seen in the Arrhenius behavior of PPO-HVBC with HVBC-rich content, where conductivity activation energy is minimized. Additionally, while higher IEC typically risks reduced membrane strength, PPO-HVBC achieves high conductivity with moderate IEC values, avoiding the mechanical drawbacks seen in other membranes requiring higher IEC levels to achieve comparable conductivities. For instance, PPO-HVBC achieves 135.9 mS cm−1 at an IEC of 1.88 mmol g−1, whereas other membranes, such as Cr-PPO-g-Q115, need an IEC of 2.50 mmol g−1 to reach similar conductivity (Fig. 20b), highlighting the efficiency of the PPO-HVBC blend structure. These interplay between HB-VBC content, quaternization efficiency, and a supportive membrane microstructure ensures a balance of high conductivity, moderate IEC, and mechanical robustness, making these blend well suited for AEM applications. Overall, mentioned studies shows that blending in AEMs enhances IEC and conductivity by increasing ionic site density and establishing efficient transport pathways with low activation energy for OH− transport, avoiding the typical trade-offs in mechanical strength associated with high IEC. 3.3.2 Impact of structural functionalisation IEC and conductivity of AEMs are directly influenced by structural functionalization, which tailors the membrane's ability to transport ions efficiently through functionalization using specific ionic groups and by creating interconnected channels that support hydrated ion mobility. However, achieving the optimal balance is essential; excessive functionalization may increase water uptake and swelling, potentially compromising mechanical integrity. Functionalization strategies that enhance IEC while controlling the phase-separated morphology are critical in optimizing both conductivity and stability, ensuring reliable performance in fuel cells and water electrolysis. In this context balancing hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments in AEM certainly have effects on phase separation and providing efficient ion pathways. Like wise, on fine-tuning of the hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments in the hyperbranched polymer HBPAEK [146] studied the role of both hydrophilic segment length and thermal conditions in optimizing the conductive performance of AEM and reported that long hydrophilic blocks in HBPAEK-x-18 membranes facilitate microphase separation, as confirmed by TEM and SAXS, leading to well-defined pathways for efficient OH− transport. This phase-separated structure enables the aggregation of conductive groups, forming more efficient ion-conducting channels which yields IEC (1.13 to 2.25 meq g−1) due to the dense packing of QA within the hydrophilic segments,which directly correlates to improved ionic conductivity from 25.6 to 66.5 mS cm−1 at 30 °C and 46.0 to 122.5 mS cm−1 at 80 °C in Fig. 20(c), surpassing the values of all the commercially available AEM mentioned in Table 2. The significant increase in conductivity with temperature was attributed to the role of hydrophilic segment length that enhanced ion mobility and water content at higher temperatures, which lower the resistance for ion transport. On the other hand incorporating hyperbranched structure in QA-BTB-based AEMs with varying branching percentage enhances OH− conductivity and reduces activation energy (E a) required for ion transport, primarily due to increased WU and free volume groups in QA-BTB [147]. This structural adaptation optimizes ion transport channels, but the extent of branching significantly impacts performance, showing that optimal branching yields significant improvement in conductivity with comparable concentration of QA where IEC lies between 1.97 and 2.14 meq g−1 in Fig. 20(d). In QA-BTB-5%, moderate branching allows effective WU and ion mobility, achieving high conductivity (Fig. 20e) (20.6 mS cm−1 at 30 °C and 95.2 mS cm−1 at 80 °C) with an E a of 27.59 kJ mol−1, lower than QA-TB’s 31.71 kJ mol−1, which suggests more efficient OH− transport. In contrast, lesser branching QA-BTB-2% because of more open structure which fails to provide ionic pathways and excessive branching in QA-BTB-8% even though shows high IEC increased cross-linking, compacting the polymer structure and narrowing ionic channels, which limits conductivity despite a higher IEC because IEC primarily measures the number of ion exchange sites, while conductivity depends on both the number of these sites and the efficiency of ion transport through the membrane. This shows that while increased branching can improve conductivity by enhancing WU, overly dense cross-linking can restrict ion mobility and reduce performance. Interestingly, the HB-PVBC(PMDETA) [158] shows the interplay between experimental and theoretical studies on IEC and how it transformed to attain the conducitivty. The steric hindrance in HB-PVBC arises from the dense packing of polymer chains, which restricts access to all of the chloromethyl groups in the structure which inhibiting from attaining a theoretical IEC value of 3.93 mmol g−1 from experiemental 2.36 mmol g−1. However, further quaternization by second time facilitates efficient ion transport by promoting microphase separation, which creates distinct hydrophilic domains that optimize pathways for ion movement resulted in superior hydroxide conductivity, measured at 39.57 mS cm−1 at 20 °C and increasing sharply to 123.01 mS cm−1 at 80 °C (Fig. 21 a). This study outline how much precision in morphology and careful control over functionalisation is necessary while fabricating hyperbranched AEM. On the other hand IEC and conductivity of hyperbranched AEMs can be systematically enhanced by optimizing QA group and crosslinking as HB-PVBC-P(DMBA) [148] shows raising the IEC from 1.27 to 1.78 mmol g−1 leads to a significant increase in both OH− and Cl− conductivity by inhibiting swelling due to crosslinked strcutures and microphase separation enhances OH− conductivity reaching over 80 mS cm−1 at 80 °C (Fig. 21b) with conductivity to WU ratio 1.1 which exemplifies the advantages of dense functionalization accompanied with crosslinking. Therefore, achieving optimal AEM performance requires a balance between high IEC for conductivity and structural design elements, like crosslinking, to control water uptake and maintaining stability(Fig. 21b). Moreover, studies on HB-PVBC-Diamine [161] demonstrate that adjusting the alkyl chain length of diamine crosslinkers effectively guides the formation of microphase-separated morphologies, creating interconnected channels that facilitate ion transport. For evaluating the effect of chain length, IEC values of around 2.70 mmol g−1 were selected for comparission and it is evident with longer chain lengths,= HBM-10C, enhances conductivity through expanded water channels and hydrogen-bond networks within the membrane Fig. 21(c). However, while extended chains can maximize conductivity, they may also lead to excessive WU, potentially compromising the mechanical integrity of the membrane as HBM-10C shows conductivity of 61.76 mS cm−1 at 80 °C yet exhibiting mechanical failure. An optimal configuration, such as the six-carbon HBM-6C, achieves a well-balanced performance, combining high ionic conductivity with moderate WU shows conductivity of 47.92 mS cm−1 at 80 °C while HBM-2C does not show appreciable value due to poor microphase separation which lacks hydration channels. Contrary to previous study that identified moderate chain lengths as optimal for balancing conductivity and stability, recent findings on pyrrolidinium-based AEM suggest that dense distribution of ionic domains, modulated by the choice of chain length specifically longer chains deliver superior performance ((HB-PVBC)-PMDA) [162]. To mitigate CO2 interference, chloride conductivity measurements offer a clear view of ion transport efficiency across different IEC values and morphologies. For example when small chain (HBM-Py1) with an IEC of 1.34 mmol g−1, shows a conductivity of 18.68 mS cm−1 and IEC of 1.60 mmol g−1, enhances conductivity to 22.07 mS cm−1 at 80 °C, confirming the relationship between IEC and increased ion transport. However, conductivity is not solely determined by IEC; the morphology induced by longer quaternization agents is crucial and it is evident from longer chain (HBM-Py2) with a lower IEC of 1.28 mmol g−1, surpasses small chain HBM-Py1-1.34 in conductivity and HBM-Py2-2.18, with an IEC of 2.18 mmol g−1, achieving 49.69 mS cm−1 at 80 °C without mechanical failure due to a more distinct microphase-separated morphology achieved by longer PMDA chains, which promotes dense pyrrolidinium cation clusters seen from SAXS analysis, forming interconnected hydrophilic channels that facilitate ion migration Fig. 21(d). These findings highlight that longer chains with dense distribution of ions enable a more organized structure, enhancing conductivity with mechanical stability. On the other hand the addition of flexible segments into hyperbranched PVBC based AEM resulted in microphase-separated architecture, which provides well-defined conduction pathways that facilitate rapid OH− transport Fig. 15(c–f) and the membrane exhibited IEC value of 1.26 mmol g−1 [143] lower than theoretical value due to heterogeneity in quaternization with hyperbranched structure which limit uniform functionalization across all available VBC sites. However, the patterned surface morphology results from chain segment self-assembly and ordered morphology from postannealing might enhances the ionic channels and thus facilitate the conductivity as shown in Fig. 21(e) as the membrane shows chloride conductivity of 19.8 mS cm−1 at 30 °C and 38.4 mS cm−1 at 80 °C, and hydroxide conductivities of 50.8 mS cm−1 at 30 °C and 85.1 mS cm−1 at 80 °C was achieved. However there is a need for more investigation as this work does not elaborate the conductivity pattern and the results insist that hyperbranched architecture shows good performance by regulating the morphology and improving the chain entanglement without additional crosslinker. Similarly Yuan et al. [145] demonstrate how careful control over branching can enhance membrane IEC and conductivity performance using hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium) and found that optimal branching (10%) supports high IEC which translates to improved conductivity at elevated temperatures. Additionally, the authors claims that optimal branching showed increased free volume using DMA where hyperbranched AEM shows low Tg compared to linear poly(aryl piperidinium) (TPP), which allows ions to navigate with minimal resistance. This high free volume, characteristic of hyperbranched polymers, provides clear ionic pathways as this configuration results in high IEC (2.21 mmol g−1) and significant conductivity (296 mS cm−1) at elevated temperatures Fig. 22 (a), reaching 1 A cm−2 at 2 V in 1 M NaOH at 80 °C for AEMWE Fig. 22(b) and AEMFC possessed outstanding power density of 1.53 W cm−2 at 80 °C under H2-O2 conditions, showcasing how well-balanced branching supports effective ion transport. Beyond this level, increasing the branching tends to reduce ion mobility due to crowding of functional sites and added structural complexity, which can hinder overall performance as conductivity decreases (Fig. 22a and b). Similarly along with branching degree and FFV, localized stacking also plays a critical role in improving the conductivity by improving ionic channel as Ma et al. [144] found that in hyper-branch poly(triethyltriindole aryl piperidinium) introducing a bulky, π-conjugated aromatic heterocyclic compound TTI as a branching point promotes localized stacking within the AEM matrix as confirmed by SAXS and 3-D photoluminescence, which combined with the FFV studied using molecular dynamics study forms effective ionic transport highways resulting in an exceptional OH− conductivity of 304.5 mS cm−1 at 80 °C in Fig. 22(c). Through molecular dynamics and DMA studies, the authors found that Tg and FFV vary with branching in hb-QPTP AEMs. Adding TTI initially increased Tg by restricting chain movement, but further branching raised FFV and lowered Tg until an optimal balance was reached as supported by molecular dynamics simulations Fig. 22(d). IEC of the hyper-branched membranes ranged from 2.0 to 2.3 mmol g−1, lower than that of the linear QPTP membrane at 2.64 mmol g−1. This difference suggests that while the introduction of branching points can effectively increase FFV, it also disperses ionic sites, causing a more heterogeneous functionalization of the polymer backbone. This dispersed arrangement reduces the density of ionizable sites, leading to a lower IEC at higher branching levels due to the less efficient incorporation of active sites. Despite the slightly reduced IEC, hyperbranched membranes achieved OH− conductivity levels surpassing linear QPTP AEMs by up to threefold. The study implies a trade-off between branching degree, FFV and IEC that require further exploration to fully understand their relationship. However, the high FFV provided by the hyper-branched structure creates substantial free volume, lowering resistance to ion conduction. This finding insist that, FFV along with the formation of ion clusters due to localized stacking, facilitates rapid ion transport, minimizing reliance on IEC for performance. Overall hyperbranched polymers offer superior IEC and conductivity, however optimizing branching degree is crucial, as increased branching can lead to crosslinking, which, while boosting IEC, may not yield high conductivity. Controlled crosslinking improves structural integrity but must be balanced to avoid swelling and degradation. Adding flexible segments improves chain entanglement, ion conductivity, and transport channels, maintaining stability. Significantly FFV in hyperbranched polymers reduces ion transport resistance, increasing conductivity beyond that of commercial membranes (Table 2). This approach yields high-performance AEMs with balanced conductivity and durability, ideal for AEMWE and AEMFC applications. 4 Performance evaluation in fuel cell and potential for electrolysers To fully grasp the impact of hyperbranched AEMs in practical applications, it is crucial to consider their performance in real-time operational environments. Although the available data on the use of hyperbranched AEMs in electrolysers is limited, this challenge can be mitigated by examining their application in fuel cells. Given that electrolysers and fuel cells operate under similar conditions, insights gleaned from the fuel cell performance of hyperbranched AEMs from Table 7 will helps to evaluate its potential in AEMWE. The relationship between conductivity and power density in AEMs highlights a complex interplay between chemical structure and performance, with varying degrees of success depending on the specific polymer architecture and composition. From the analysed AEM, the hyperbranched Poly (4-vinylbenzyl chloride)-N, N, N’, N'-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine [161], demonstrates a relatively low conductivity of 61.76 mS cm−1, accompanied by a notably low power density of 0.097 W cm−2. This suggests that the dense hyperbranched architecture, while contributing to ion transport path, it is worth noting that the precise microstructure necessary to achieve optimal ionic transport in systems like AEMWE and AEMFC remains an area of ongoing investigation. Conversely, the hyperbranched Poly(arylene ether ketone) [146] exhibits a significantly higher conductivity of 122.5 mS cm−1 but only modestly improves power density, reaching 0.188 W cm−2. The presence of arylene ether ketone units within the polymer backbone likely enhances ionic conduction due to the flexibility afforded by the ether linkages. However, the overall hyperbranched structure may still limit performance, potentially by restricting ion mobility at elevated current densities where efficient power generation is paramount. In contrast, poly (phenylene oxide)-hyperbranched poly (4-vinylbenzyl chloride) [121] achieves a very high conductivity of 135.9 mS cm−1, yet the power density remains low at 0.0711 W cm−2 at 60 °C. This substantiate that while ion conductivity is often considered a key indicator of effective ion transport within AEMs, it is not sufficient to solely rely on conductivity metrics to assess the overall performance of fuel cell and electrolysers. Several additional factors contribute to performance limitations and a critical consideration is the compatibility between the ionomer used in the catalyst layer and the membrane material itself. Disparities in polymer chemistry between the ionomer and membrane can result in discontinuities in ion transport pathways, leading to suboptimal ionic transfer and a subsequent reduction in system efficiency. Furthermore, conductivity measurements are typically conducted under fully hydrated conditions (100% relative humidity), which do not accurately represent operational conditions. In crosslinked AEMs, although crosslinking enhances mechanical stability, it inherently restricts water mobility, resulting in a marked decline in conductivity as the relative humidity decreases. This phenomenon is heightened at high current densities, where cathode dry-out can occur, even under conditions of high humidity supply. Such dehydration impairs ionic conductivity, causing a rapid decline in performance. While this issue is more pronounced in fuel cells, it poses less of a challenge in water electrolysis, where hydration is more effectively maintained. However, the hyperbranched structure, despite its advantages in ion conduction, may compromise power generation efficiency, possibly due to suboptimal interactions with catalysts or issues related to gas diffusion within the membrane. Additionally cross-linked polymer structure suffers from lower water uptake especially at elevated temperatures, this can compromise ionic conductivity of the fuel cell cathode ionomer and cathode-AEM interface. Branched Tröger's base (QA-BTB-5%) [147] AEM, with moderate conductivity of 95.2 mS cm−1, yielded a moderate power density of 0.548 W cm−2. This indicates that while the branched structure supports a fast level of ionic transport, this is dependent on structure been fully humidified. Upon AEM fuel cell operation, cathode drying is known to occur and is highly dependent on membrane water transport. Lower water uptake, lower water permeability and faster dehydration with temperature can all result in the seen limited power output at high temperature and current densities. The structural design of this membrane likely creates a balance between mechanical integrity, ionic and water transport, though not optimized for maximum power density. However, more promising results are observed with the hyperbranched poly(triethyltrindoaryl piperidinium)- [144] with FFV demonstrates an extremely high conductivity of 304.5 mS cm−1, coupled with a significant power density of 1.45 W cm−2. This combination suggests that the highly conductive triethyltrindoaryl piperidinium groups effectively facilitate ionic and water transport and catalyst utilization, resulting in robust fuel cell performance. Similarly, the hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium)-1,3,5-triacetylbenzene with a FFV shows high conductivity of 296 mS cm−1 and achieves the highest power density in the series, at 1.53 W cm−2. The piperidinium-based structure, in conjunction with the 1,3,5-triacetylbenzene [145] component, appears to strike an optimal balance between ionic conductivity and structural properties, thereby enhancing overall fuel cell performance. Additionally in AEMWE it exhibited a current density of 1 A cm−2 at 2 V, which points to significant overpotentials even with its high conductivity of 296 mS cm−1. This elevated voltage requirement suggests that, while the membrane effectively supports ion transport, there are limitations in reaction kinetics and mass transport that need to be addressed. For example, Oxygen evolution catalyst requires formation of metal OOH species e.g. Ni or Ni-FeOOH which in turn require OH− insertion in the structure coupled with increase of metal oxidation state. These OH− ions can only be provided by mobile OH– and usually accompanied by insertion of cations K+. The OH− ions cannot simply be provided by AEM counter OH− due to charge neutrality and immobility of cationic groups. In other words, OER catalyst activity and stability is pH dependent and AEM as solid electrolyte fed with de-ionised water showed OER activity lower than these at pH 11 [44]. On other hand, AEM electrolyser fed with liquid electrolyte are less suspectable to dehydration encountered by fuel cell cathode. Overall, it is inferred that while the hyperbranched architecture AEMs offers dense functionality and enhanced microphase separation with interconnected pathways, leading to higher ionic conductivity, the FFV within this architecture plays a critical role in translating these improved properties into real-time performance. FFV significantly reduces ion transport resistance which will consequently improve the overall efficiency of the membrane in practical applications. Therefore, future research should focus on optimizing the balance between hyperbranched architecture with FFV. By fine-tuning these factors, there will be a possiblility to lower the operating voltage, thereby enhancing the overall efficiency of both fuel cells and electrolysers. This optimization could pave the way for more effective and sustainable energy conversion technologies. 4.1 Fundamental membrane requirements: AEMFCs vs. AEMWEs AEM used in both AEMFCs and AEMWE share the core requirement of high ionic conductivity and chemical stability in alkaline environments. However, the operational demands diverge significantly. AEMFCs operate under fuel cell conditions where the membrane must efficiently transport hydroxide ions (OH−) generated at the cathode while maintaining a barrier to crossover of reactants such as hydrogen and oxygen. The membrane's performance is critical to achieving high power density, low resistance, and long-term stability. AEM and ionomer in AEMFC need to show improved water retention and water permeation to mitigate cathode drying issues as discussed above. AEMWE, on the other hand, requires the membrane to facilitate the transport of OH− from the cathode to the anode, where water splitting occurs to generate oxygen and hydrogen. The membrane must withstand highly oxidative conditions at the anode and high-water content, while maintaining mechanical integrity. AEM also need to withstand the supporting KOH electrolyte typically used in AEMWE to support the catalysis as discussed above. Given these differences, AEMs designed for AEMFCs must undergo careful evaluation and modification to meet the harsher and more demanding conditions of AEMWE as discussed below. 4.2 Potential of hyperbranched AEMFC membranes in AEMWE The adaptation of AEMFC membranes for AEMWE presents an opportunity to leverage the advancements made in AEMFC technology for efficient green hydrogen production. The high conductivity and selective ion transport properties of AEMFC membranes, combined with strategic enhancements for stability and durability, can lead to the development of high-performance AEMWE systems. The rationale for employing hyperbranched AEMs in electrolysers lies in their ability to conduct hydroxide ions effectively, which is essential in both fuel cells and electrolysers. When adapting or fabricating AEMs for transitioning from AEMFCs to AEMWE, a thorough understanding of polymer characteristics and several critical factors must be considered to ensure optimal membrane performance and longevity under the more demanding conditions of water electrolysis. 4.2.1 Stability Oxidative stability The AEMWE environment is characterized by high oxidative stress, necessitating polymers with superior oxidative stability. During the operation of an AEMWE, the membrane and ionomer at the anode is exposed to reactive oxygen species (ROS) like hydroxyl and peroxyl radicals. These radicals are highly reactive and can initiate chain reactions that degrade the membrane, compromising its mechanical and chemical integrity. The degradation process typically begins with the attack of these radicals on vulnerable sites within the functional groups attached to the polymer backbone. Once these functional groups are removed or degraded, the polymer backbone itself becomes susceptible to oxidative degradation. This process can lead to a complete breakdown of the membrane structure, reducing its effectiveness and lifespan. However, from the reviewed literature the PP0-HVBC [121] exhibited good oxidative stability by maintaining 95% weight after immersing in Fenton's reagent at 60 °C for 24 h and at room temperature for 30 days, the membranes still maintained good shapes by exhibiting weight losses less than 15%. This proves that the combination of linear and hyperbranched polymer could be adapted for AEMFC as well as AEMWE. Alkaline stability Alkaline stability is crucial for the durability and performance of AEMs used in alkaline environments, such as in water electrolysis due to need of using supporting electrolyte to enhance catalysis and improve stability of electrocatalyst and metallic bipolar plates. In these conditions, OH− can initiate degradation through nucleophilic attacks, Hofmann elimination, and dealkylation, particularly targeting the cationic functional groups like QA. These degradation processes lead to the breakdown of functional groups and compromise the membrane's IEC and mechanical integrity. Among the analysed AEM hyperbranched poly(aryl piperidinium)-1,3,5-triacetylbenzene [145], hyperbranched poly(triethyltriindolearyl piperidinium) [144] showed a alkaline stability for 2000 h at 1 M KOH, 80 °C. It is attributed to hyperbranched polymers, by design, have a dense terminal functionality as seen from Fig. 22(d) ensures that the membrane has a large number of active sites in the terminal end that are not submerged within the polymer matrix but are instead readily available on the surface, which enhances the reactivity and stability of the membrane [162,143]. This is particularly important in the harsh alkaline environments encountered during water electrolysis, where the membrane needs to maintain its functionality and resist degradation over time. It is interesting to see the stability of some of the promising cationic head groups including nitrogen spirocycles and isoindoline in hyperbranched AEMs. 4.2.2 Conductivity Efficient ion transport is essential for minimizing voltage losses in AEMWE. This requires membrane with high IEC and well-designed ion-conducting channels. The membrane must be able to support a high density of functional groups and maintain an optimal spatial arrangement of these functional groups within the polymer matrix, as it influences the formation of continuous ion-conducting pathways, which are essential for achieving high OH− conductivity. Among the reviewed membranes, AEM from [144,145] shows excellent conductivity 296 and 304.5 mS cm−1 due to FFV. FFV refers to the unoccupied space as seen from Fig. 22(d) within the polymer matrix [173] that can accommodate water molecules and hydroxide ions. In hyperbranched polymers, the three-dimensional, highly branched structure leads to an increased FFV compared to linear polymers [174]. This higher FFV is beneficial for several reasons. First, it allows the membrane to absorb more water, which is essential for the dissociation of hydroxide ions. The presence of water molecules in the membrane facilitates the mobility of ions, thereby enhancing ionic conductivity. Second, the increased FFV ensures that there is sufficient space within the polymer matrix for the ions to move freely, reducing the resistance to ion transport [145]. This results in a membrane that is more efficient in conducting hydroxide ions as which is crucial for AEM water electrolysis. The cross linking needs to be tailored for AEMFC and AEMWE applications. The former is suspectable to cathode drying and relies on water uptake from vapour phase and water back diffusion from anode and therefore requires lower degree of cross linking. The latter, is fed with supporting liquid electrolyte and is less suspectable to drying. 4.2.3 Mechanical durability The membrane employed in AEMWE must manage swelling effectively to maintain mechanical integrity since excessive water uptake can lead to significant swelling, causing dimensional instability and potential mechanical failure. These channels facilitate efficient ion transport while maintaining the mechanical integrity of the membrane. The phenomenon of microphase separation in AEMs plays a significant role in maintaining the membrane hydration and durability [175]. This separation leads to the formation of microdomains, where the hydrophilic regions form continuous channels that facilitate the transport of hydroxide ions. These channels are critical for the membrane's ionic conductivity, as they provide a direct pathway for ions to move through the membrane. The hydrophobic matrix, on the other hand, ensures that the membrane retains its structural integrity, preventing it from swelling excessively or degrading over time. Although, it can be induced in linear polymer as well, the unique architecture of hyperbranched AEMs [121,148,162] significantly enhances this microphase separation, resulting in well-defined ion-conducting pathways with sufficient mechanical integrity which is vital for AEMWE. 4.2.4 Viability While the integration of hyperbranched polymers into AEMs may initially elevate production costs, their economic viability for large-scale application remains promising due to the efficiency of their synthesis via one-pot methods, which supports mass production. The increased upfront costs are justified and potentially offset by the superior performance and enhanced durability these polymers confer, which are critical for the rigorous operational demands of AEMWE. Consequently, hyperbranched polymers not only fulfill the technical requirements for high-performance AEMs but also offer scalability, making them a compelling choice for commercial AEMWE applications where both cost-effectiveness and long-term operational efficiency are paramount. 5 Overview of research progress AEMs were first used commercially for electrodialysis in initiating their role in ion exchange applications. Subsequently, their incorporation in lithium-ion batteries marked a significant milestone in energy storage. A pivotal development occurred when different cations based AEMs were synthesized, advancing the field by improving ion conductivity. Further, with metal cations and the first alkali-stabilized sulfonyl AEM were introduced, significantly improving membrane stability in alkaline conditions. A further refinement came in through in situ polymerization, eliminating the need for post-functionalization processes. In addition, doping with graphene oxide offered better mechanical properties and durability. Most recently, a cross-linked AEMs with cyclic cations are getting attention, representing an important step in enhancing the structure and performance of AEMs for AEMFCs and AEMWEs. A robust and long-lasting AEM is crucial for ensuring the efficiency and longevity of both AEMFC and AEMWE systems. By 2050, it is projected that AEMWE stacks will need to achieve a lifespan of 100,000–120,000 h. Thus, the polymer structure and architecture play a vital role in meeting these targets. However, the choice of membrane materials is limited by alkaline degradation, which affects the long-term stability of the stack. Although linear aliphatic polymers, especially those containing spirocyclic and heterocyclic groups, show promising results, they require careful functionalization and multiple steps to achieve the necessary stability and performance. Moreover, linear polymers are prone to leaching, leading to the loss of functional groups after prolonged exposure to alkaline environments. Cross-linking, while improving mechanical stability, can hinder ion conduction pathways, making it essential to strike a balance between structural integrity and ionic transport. Continuous research efforts have yielded more promising results for AEMs designed for hydrogen production. Notably, the introduction of hyperbranched polymers has been a breakthrough, particularly with the incorporation of cyclic cations. These innovations have led to substantial improvements in ionic conductivity, with values reaching up to 296 mS cm−1 [145], 304.5 mS cm−1 [144] an unprecedented milestone compared to earlier materials. Hyperbranched architectures offer higher terminal functionality and a possible enhanced alkaline stability, both of which are critical for optimizing AEMs in high-efficiency energy conversion devices like fuel cells and electrolysers. Furthermore, cyclic cations not only improve conductivity but also mitigate degradation issues that have historically limited AEM durability in alkaline environments. These developments position hyperbranched polymers and cyclic cation-based membranes as promising candidates for future innovations in AEM technology. 6 Conclusions In conclusion, the AEM technology has gained substantial attention due to its cost-effective approach and efficiency. The AEM employed in AEMFC and AEMWE play a crucial role in enhancing efficiency and reducing cost. Hence, achieving high conductivity in AEMs without compromising stability and mechanical properties remains a significant challenge for long-term operation and commercial viability. Given this hyperbranched polymers present a promising solution to the ongoing challenges by enhancing key properties. Hyperbranched AEMs contain a highly branched, three-dimensional architecture that exhibits structure-dependent ionic conductivity and alkaline stability. Numerous branching groups were explored that create an open network to increase the free volume and WU capacity without causing excessive swelling. The structural advantage of hyperbranched AEM facilitates the formation of continuous ion transport pathways, improving ionic mobility by reducing the ion transfer resistance leads to higher conductivity. In some cases, the synergistic combination of linear with hyperbranched polymers is found to enhance ionic conductivity and alkaline stability through the unique and strategically designed branched architecture. Among the analysed AEMs, some of the promising results include hyperbranched poly (aryl piperidinium)-1,3,5-triacetylbenzene and hyperbranched poly (triethyltriindolearyl piperidinium) with appreciable WU, SR and good alkaline stability of 2000 h is promising while progressing towards achieving a target of 80,000 h, and they shows a very high conductivity of 296–304.5 mS cm−1 at 80 °C with good mechanical stability in wet condition. These approaches are very effective to develop AEM for commercial AEMFC and AMEWE applications, allowing various degree of freedom in achieving a balance of properties. Recommendations for future research Advancing hydrogen production technologies, particularly through AEMWE, necessitates addressing the dual challenges of achieving long-term stability and high ionic conductivity under alkaline conditions. The degradation of polymer backbones and cationic groups in such environments remains a significant hurdle. Recent studies on hyperbranched polymers have shown promise in enhancing both stability and conductivity in AEMs. For instance, hyperbranched AEMs have demonstrated high conductivity and prolonged chemical stability under alkaline conditions. Future research should focus on designing hyperbranched polymers with optimized degrees of branching and strategic substituents to inhibit degradation. Incorporating chemically stable cations with a higher half-life, such as spirocyclic structures, into the polymer backbone could further enhance resilience in alkaline environments. Tethering these cations to hyperbranched backbones may create robust ionic channels, improving both stability and conductivity. Additionally, hyperbranched polymers inherently offer high FFV, which can increase conductivity. However, further research is required to understand and control the relationship between branching, ion exchange capacity, and the extent of crosslinking. Investigating these research pathways will address critical stability and conductivity challenges, ultimately facilitating the development of more efficient and durable electrolysis technologies. Tamilazhagan Palanivel is a Ph.D. student in Energy and Materials Science at the Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières , under the supervision of Prof. Bruno G. Pollet and Prof. Mohamed Mamlouk. He holds both a bachelor’s and a master’s degree in Polymer Science and Engineering from Anna University, India. His research focuses on synthesis of anion exchange membranes to improve green hydrogen production through water electrolysis. Mohamed Mamlouk is a Professor of Electrochemical Engineering at Newcastle University with over 20 years of expertise in modeling, fabrication, optimization, and diagnostics of electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices. He leads several key projects focusing on hydrogen production and battery technologies, including sustainable recycling of electric vehicle batteries, lithium-ion battery recovery and recycling, ocean renewable energy conversion, and anion exchange membrane water electrolysis from low-grade water sources. His research aims to enhance the design and performance of electrochemical reactors through mathematical modeling and to develop diagnostic tools and materials that improve the sustainability and stability of electrochemical devices. He is a Fellow of the UK Higher Education Academy and a member of the International Energy Agency (IEA) Hydrogen Technology Collaboration Programme, along with other organizations such as the Electrochemical Society (ECS), the European Energy Research Alliance (EERA), and the Society of Chemical Industry (SCI). Bruno G. Pollet is a Full Professor of Chemistry at the Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières (UQTR) in Canada and a Fellow of the UK Royal Society of Chemistry. He is a President of the Green Hydrogen Division of the International Association for Hydrogen Energy (IAHE). He is also member of the Board of Directors of the Canadian Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Association (CHFCA) and Hydrogen Québec. He is also leading H2CAN 2.0, a cluster of H2FC R&D groups in Canada. His research covers a wide range of areas from the development of novel materials for low-temperature fuel cells and water electrolysers, hydrogen production from pure, waste, & saline waters, as well as oxygenated solutions and CO2-saturated waters to fuel cell and electrolyser systems, demonstrators, and prototypes. His research also focuses on sonoelectrochemistry to produce fuel cell/electrolyser materials and to improve electrochemical processes. Professor Pollet is a member of organizations like the Electrochemical Society (ECS) and the International Society of Electrochemistry (ISE) and serves as a scientific advisor to leading Canadian hydrogen companies, including Hydrogen Optimized and Cipher Neutron Inc. Rajangam Vinodh is currently a post-doctoral researcher at the Hydrogen Research Institute (IRH), Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières (UQTR), where he has been since May 2022. He completed his bachelor’s and master’s degrees in chemistry from the University of Madras, India, and obtained his Ph.D. from Anna University in 2012, specializing in membrane electrode assemblies for alkaline membrane fuel cells. Dr. Vinodh previously held positions as an Assistant Professor at Hanseo University and as a post-doctoral researcher at Pusan National University in South Korea. He is an expert in electrochemical workstations and energy storage systems, including supercapacitors and CO2 adsorption devices. To date, he has authored 140 international publications, contributed to five book chapters, and reviewed for over 30 international journals.

coredata.dc:description: Anion-exchange membrane water electrolysers (AEMWEs) and fuel cells (AEMFCs) are critical technologies for converting renewable resources into green hydrogen (H2), where anion-exchange membranes (AEMs) play a vital role in efficiently transporting hydroxide ions (OH−) and minimizing fuel crossover, thus enhancing overall efficiency. While conventional AEMs with linear, side-chain, and block polymer architectures show promise through functionalization, their long-term performance remains a concern. To address this, hyperbranched polymers offer a promising alternative due to their three-dimensional structure, higher terminal functionality, and ease of functionalization. This unique architecture provides interconnected ion transport pathways, fractional free volume, and enhanced long-term stability in alkaline environments. Recent studies have achieved conductivities as high as 304.5 mS cm−1, attributed to their improved fractional free volume and microphase separation in hyperbranched AEMs. This review explores the chemical, mechanical, and ionic properties of hyperbranched AEMs in AEMFCs and assesses their potential for application in AEMWEs. Strategies such as blending and structural functionalisation have significantly improved the properties by promoting microphase separation and increasing the density of cationic groups on the polymer surface. The review provides essential insights for future research, highlighting the challenges and opportunities in developing high-performance hyperbranched AEMs to advance hydrogen energy infrastructure.

coredata.dc:title: Exploring properties of hyperbranched polymers in anion exchange membranes for fuel cells and its potential integration for water electrolysis: A review
